headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. My name is Shirley, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the XL Capital Ltd. Fourth Quarter and Full Year Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call o
componenttext: Good afternoon. My name is Shirley, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the XL Capital Ltd. Fourth Quarter and Full Year Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to Dave Radulski, XL's Director of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Shirley. Good evening, and welcome to XL Capital's Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2009 Conference Call. This call is being simultaneously webcast on XL's website at www.xlcapital.com. We posted to our website several documents, including our quar
componenttext: Thank you, Shirley. Good evening, and welcome to XL Capital's Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2009 Conference Call. This call is being simultaneously webcast on XL's website at www.xlcapital.com. We posted to our website several documents, including our quarterly financial supplement and our fixed income portfolio data. On our call today, Mike McGavick, XL Capital's CEO, will offer opening remarks; Simon Rich, our Interim CFO, will review our financial results; followed by Chief Investment Officer, Sarah Street, who'll discuss our investment portfolio. Dave Duclos, our Chief Executive of Insurance Operations; and Jamie Veghte, our Chief Executive of Reinsurance Operations, will review their segment results and market conditions. Mike will discuss our guidance for 2010, and we will open it up for your questions. Before they begin, I'd like to remind you that certain of the matters we'll discuss today are forward-looking statements. These statements are based on current plans, estimates and expectations. Forward-looking statements involve inherent risks and uncertainties and a number of factors could cause actual results to differ materially from those contained in the forward-looking statements, and therefore, you should not place undue reliance on them. Forward-looking statements are sensitive to many factors, including those identified in our annual report on Form 10-K, our quarterly reports on Form 10-Q and other documents on file with the SEC that could cause actual results to differ materially from those contained in the forward-looking statements. Forward-looking statements speak only as of the date of which they were made and we undertake no obligation publicly to revise any forward-looking statement in response to new information, future developments or otherwise.Now in connection with our previously announced proposed redomestication to Ireland from the Cayman Islands, XL Capital has filed a preliminary proxy statement with the SEC. Investors and security holders are urged to read the definitive proxy statement related to the post-redomestication when it becomes available, because it will contain important information. We will not be taking questions with respect to redomestication today and refer you to the proxy statement for additional information. XL Capital, its directors and certain employees, may be soliciting proxies from shareholders in favor of the proposed redomestication. You can find information about these individuals and XL Capital's definitive proxy statement for the 2009 annual general meeting filed with the SEC on March 9, 2009. And you can obtain free copies of the definitive proxy statement when it becomes available and other documents filed by XL with the SEC at both the SEC's website and at www.xlcapital.com. With that, I'll turn it over to Mike McGavick.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good evening. The results we reported tonight confirmed that XL is, once again, a market of choice for brokers and customers around the world. The evidence is clear. Our P&C top line for the fourth quarter was within three points of the same quarter last
componenttext: Good evening. The results we reported tonight confirmed that XL is, once again, a market of choice for brokers and customers around the world. The evidence is clear. Our P&C top line for the fourth quarter was within three points of the same quarter last year, a fairly remarkable result given our replanning at the beginning of 2009. And as you can see in our highlights on Slide 3, our P&C combined ratio was a very solid 96.4% for the quarter and 93.6% for the full year.But wait, what may be most remarkable is that we engineered this turnaround and maintained our underwriting discipline and historically prudent reserving standards in the depth of a continued soft market. By lowering our expense base and increasing both our efficiency and capital strength, we have certainly improved our current performance, perhaps more importantly, we have put XL in a position of competitive advantage to endure the soft market and for when the P&C markets turned the corner. On the asset side, we continued to realign our investment portfolio. We worked down our legacy assets, primarily Non-Agency RMBS and CLOs to a level where we can now move on from de-risking to optimizing our portfolio. This means we see future OTTI and realized losses as being made as economics unfold rather than as a result of aggressive portfolio repositioning.So while we will certainly -- rationally if we find good opportunities to sell, we'd expect the bulk of our legacy positions now to wind down over time through natural cash flows and maturities. This results in a portfolio more closely reflecting a traditional P&C asset based, thus allowing the earnings from our P&C franchise to go toward building book value, and our book value did grow in the fourth quarter. For the third straight quarter, as we recorded a 3% increase in book value per share to $26.60 (sic) [$24.60] and a 4% increase in tangible book value per share to $22.13. Total shareholder equity increased from $9.2 billion to $9.4 billion in the fourth quarter. For the full year, our 2009 net income of $206.6 million compared to a 2008 net loss of $2.6 billion. A turnaround indeed. We generated an operating and return on equity for the year of 13.5%. And in 2009, our tangible book value per ordinary share grew by 72%. While no one can state with certainty when or how the underwriting cycle will turn, we believe the steps we have taken put XL in a position of significant strength. We are ready both to endure well the industries current challenges and take the advantage of the opportunities that can come when the hardening market whenever it comes. And with that, I'll turn it over to Simon.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike, and good evening. Operating income was $235.8 million or $0.69 per ordinary share for the fourth quarter, with an annualized operating ROE of 11.4%, compared to $189.5 million, $0.57 per ordinary share and 12.4%, respectively in the prior ye
componenttext: Thanks, Mike, and good evening. Operating income was $235.8 million or $0.69 per ordinary share for the fourth quarter, with an annualized operating ROE of 11.4%, compared to $189.5 million, $0.57 per ordinary share and 12.4%, respectively in the prior year quarter. Operating income for the year was $917.3 million, resulting in an operating ROE of 13.5%. With a lower ROE for the quarter, reflecting our growing shareholder's equity.Turning to our summary financial results Slide 4. P&C net premiums earned were down 10.6% in the fourth quarter, primarily due to the rolling effects of prior periods lower written premium. This rate of change is better than previous quarters, reflecting the improving level of gross premiums written relative to the prior year that we have reported quarter-on-quarter this year. We expect the improving trends in net premiums earned to continue into 2010.The P&C combined ratio for fourth quarter of 96.4% benefited from favorable prior development of $30.8 million compared to $268.3 million in the prior year quarter. The latter included a one-time benefit of $81 million from an agreement in connection with the business we acquired from Winterthur. Our underlying combined ratio, excluding prior development, natural catastrophes and restructuring costs was a full 8.8 points better for the quarter than in the prior year, and was also 1.5 points better for the year as a whole.Our operating expenses of $289.1 million for the quarter were $8.7 million higher than the prior year quarter. However, the current quarter included $21.8 million in restructuring charges, $12.1 million more of performance-related compensation in the prior year quarter, some costs related to the redomestication of our parent company to Ireland, as well as being impacted negatively by foreign exchange rate fluctuations. Our underlying expense base is now much lower than a year ago. In fact, our two restructuring initiatives are now essentially complete and are both within our initial cost assessment. We captured the targeted savings and our guidance for operating expenses in 2010 reflects this lower run rate. Our tax charge for the quarter was $54.7 million. After adjusting for the impact of net realized gains and losses on investments, which have a low effective tax rate, the underlying effect of tax rate was 21.5% for the quarter and 14.5% for the year. The rates for the quarter reflected the impact of our year end reserve review, and also contained a number of non-recurring items, which together resulted in a disproportionately high level of profit to rising in higher tax jurisdictions. These items added $29 million to our tax charge for the quarter. But looking forward to 2010, we expect our underlying tax rate to be between 12% and 15%, which is consistent with our guidance for prior years.Our book value increased for the third consecutive quarter from $23.84 per share at September 30, to $24.60 per share at year end, with the main driver being our operating earnings. This was offset by net realized losses on investments in the quarter of $254.8 million net of tax. This total included $10.9 million from the sale of XL Re Life America, a transaction that closed in the quarter.As set out on Slide 7, we end the year on a strong capital position with over $12 billion in total capital, an increase of over 23% from the position of December 2008. We also have in excess of $1.5 billion of cash and investments at the holding company to maintain financial flexibility. In this regard, we are well positioned for 2010. Now over to Sarah to discuss our investment portfolio.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good evening, we've made great progress on our de-risking plans during the quarter. We took advantage of what we believe to be a technically driven rally in certain asset classes to reduce our holdings in a number of legacy positions. We sold $1.2 billion
componenttext: Good evening, we've made great progress on our de-risking plans during the quarter. We took advantage of what we believe to be a technically driven rally in certain asset classes to reduce our holdings in a number of legacy positions. We sold $1.2 billion of assets including CMBS, a Non-Agency RMBS, where we saw market prices approaching intrinsic values or where the underlying clashful [ph] (35.14) is still exposed to weak fundamental. We also reduced a number of the hybrid securities in the Life portfolio through both sales and tenders.We have now reached 80% of our targeted P&C de-risking in terms of reducing the potential negative mark-to-market if the market events of January 2007 grew to March 2009 were to repeat themselves. As Mike mentioned, further reductions in remaining legacy assets principally Non-Agency RMBS and CLOs will likely occur over time from natural cash flows maturities and compel where the economics make sense.Slide 8 summarizes our de-risking actions to date as well as for the full year. During 2009, we have reduced our exposures to volatile asset classes by $5.6 billion. Slide 9 compares the current asset mix of the portfolio at the beginning of the current asset mix to the portfolio at the beginning of the credit crisis at June 2007. We have a substantial reduction in non-agency structured credit and other risk assets. Given where we standing today, we are now focusing on the optimal realignment of the P&C portfolio rather than pure de-risking actions. The competition of the P&C portfolio is not as close to our strategic benchmark as we would like it to be, but we are still somewhat defensively positioned. The best example is that we are overweight government and related sectors and underweight high-quality corporate. However, given what interest rates are currently low, we will take our time and be patient to moving towards our strategic benchmarks looking through attractive spread and absolute yields, but also a good risk adjusted return.I will also that due to the decision to put the Life portfolio into run off and given that we run these portfolios on a closely match basis to the liabilities, we designated $546 million worth of Euro-denominated long-duration government within our Life operations account to maturity, which means that interest rate movement will no longer impact our book value from these holdings on a U.S. GAAP basis.Turning to the fourth quarter investment results. During the quarter, the investment market was relatively quiet, leading to a positive mark-to-market of $112 million. Slide 10 shows the drivers of essentially spread tightening with [indiscernible] (37.41) offset by increasing rates in both the U.S. and the U.K. Slide 11 shows our net investment income on the P&C and Corporate portfolio with $233 million, a decline of 24% compared to the prior year quarter, and down 2% relative to third quarter. At the asset associate with the exited structured products businesses are a much smaller component of our portfolio now. We will now focus on P&C and Corporate net investment income in 2010.Lower net investment income continues to be driven by the floating rate assets and defensive positions in cash and government. The P&C book yield remains stable at 3.5% rest of expenses and duration is unchanged to 2.9 years. We continue to prudently redeploy cash, sales proceeds and maturity achieved a blended reinvestment rate in the P&C portfolio of 3% during the quarter.Our net income from investment from affiliate was $26 million, reflecting strong 2.4% returns in our equity accounted alternative portfolio and a favorable third quarter mark-to-market impact from our private investments. During the quarter, we realized losses of $264 million, including a $121 million of OTTI charges, primarily on now below investment grade Non-Agency RMBS securities.Our net realized losses through sales, as I talked about earlier, was $132 million, excluding $11 million related to the sale of XL Re Life America. Now over to Dave to talk about our insurance operations.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sarah. Insurance results for the fourth quarter were strong and exceeded the expectations we set in February 2009, despite the challenging macroeconomic conditions impacting many of our clients. Although renewable premiums remain down as a resu
componenttext: Thank you, Sarah. Insurance results for the fourth quarter were strong and exceeded the expectations we set in February 2009, despite the challenging macroeconomic conditions impacting many of our clients. Although renewable premiums remain down as a result of exposure base reductions globally, both underwriting income and revenues were better than expected. Our combined ratio of 98% for the quarter was five points greater than our Q4 2008 results of 93%, which have been favorably impacted by prior year reserve releases and the Winterthur-related gains Simon mentioned.Adjusting for restructuring charges, the Insurance segment's Q4 '09 combined ratio was a very respectable 96.2%. On a full year basis, excluding the benefits of prior year development and restructuring charges, we achieved a combined ratio of 99% in 2009 compared to a 104.2% combined ratio in 2008. Gross premiums written declined 5.9% or $64 million from Q4 2008, significantly better than the first half decline of 26% and continues improving trends we saw since mid-February. The small decline is due to underwriting actions, determination of two MGA programs specifically, the continued global economic pressures and our push for rates, partially offset by increase to the renewal retentions and new business.Net premiums earned were down 7% or $66 million, mostly due to earn through of lower gross premiums written, as well as FX movements, which accounted for $23 million. On the loss side, our strong Q4 2009 loss ratio of 64.4% reflects both very limited cat activity and relatively low large loss activity in our property book.My last comment on financial results relates to our Q4 '09 operating expense ratio of 21.5%. While 1.4. points greater than Q4 '08, when normalized for the restructuring charges, the ratio is 19.7% for the quarter and 17.7% year-to-date. This is in line with expectations and reflects decisions that we made and communicated to you earlier in the year.Before I move on to market conditions, a few words on subprime and Madoff. For these events, the number of new reported incidents decreased significantly as we move through 2009. Specifically, during the fourth quarter, there was only new policy notice added to the list of potential policy exposures that we are tracking related to subprime and the related credit crisis for years 2007 and 2008. For Madoff, there were two reported new notices in the fourth quarter. We will continue our regular monitoring of these matters due to their ultimate resolution and it's most recent activity reinforces our confidence in current reserve levels.Regarding the market, we continue to see clear and steady improvements in retentions and new business admissions throughout the book, and Q4 was no exception. Our premium retentions ended the year just under 80% for all lines despite the challenging market and economic conditions, with Property and Casualty lines in the low to mid-80s.Fourth quarter pricing also showed modest, but continued improvement with an aggregate price change of plus 1.4%. We saw more meaningful price increase as reflected in professional plus 2%, and aerospace at plus 9%. Property rates were down 2% for the quarter.Looking forward to 2010, I can also share some preliminary insights. In Continental Europe, we're just under 50% of the book renews. On '11, we experienced strong retentions again across all product lines, casualty at 88%, property at 86% based on accounts renewed today. Indications in other regions are also at or near historical levels.With regards to pricing, initial indications based on January 2010 renewals reflect continued albeit small rate improvement. With the rate movement currently projected at plus 1%, compared to a rate of decline of minus 2% in January 2009. And while we worked hard to keep loss business to a minimum in 2009 and we succeeded during our January renewals, we've been very successful at winning back some business that didn't move.Looking back at 2009, what's important is we can say one thing, we did what we intended to do this past year. Renewing existing books of business with improved rate outcomes. Selectively, writing new business at the right price, taking the necessary actions to lower our expenses and all are remaining disciplined and are underwriting and engage with our brokers and clients. And now to Jamie to cover Reinsurance.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dave, and good evening. Underwriting results for the segment were excellent with quarterly combined ratio of 92.6% in challenging market condition. This compares to a combined ratio of 79.6% in the fourth quarter of 2008. Excluding the benefit of
componenttext: Thanks, Dave, and good evening. Underwriting results for the segment were excellent with quarterly combined ratio of 92.6% in challenging market condition. This compares to a combined ratio of 79.6% in the fourth quarter of 2008. Excluding the benefit of prior year reserve releases, we achieve the combined ratio of 97%, which compares to 97.4% in 2008.Turning to top line, gross written premiums in the quarter were $133 million, a 28% increase over 2008. However, excluding the impact of a commutation on a structured products contracts in 2008, gross written premium in the quarter declined by about 5%.For the full year, we had a combined ratio of 82.1%, which compares favorably to the 90.4% combined at 2008. Excluding prior year releases, the combined ratio for 2009 was 96%, a 9.7 point improvement over 2008. This improvement relates primarily to our lower level of property catastrophe and risk losses in 2009 and a shift in business mix.Gross written premiums for the year declined 17.7% to approximately $1.9 billion, reflecting competitive market condition, particularly in long-tail lines. Net premiums earned for the year totaled approximately $1.6 billion, a 20% decline. As we've said repeatedly over the year, we will shrink our portfolio when we don't feel market conditions warrant deploying our capital. Overall, we are very pleased with our 2009 underwriting performance.Turning to market conditions, we had a very successful January 1 renewal despite the challenging market conditions. We entered the renewal season with $941 million of renewable premium and ended up writing $1 billion with 6% increase. Almost 50% of this increase or $28 million of written premium was driven by recaptured business that we had loss at the end of 2008, due to security concerns by customers.The remainder of the increase was driven by selected new business opportunity and increased tax capacity in certain geographies. Broadly, we would describe the renewal season as competitive but orderly. Many firm orders came in quite late, but the brokers had a very little difficulty placing even the largest of programs, provided pricing clear the major-league markets. We continue to see customers increased retentions and push for improved conditions. Direct cat renewals showed risk adjusted reductions of 7% to 10% in the U.S., and averaged 5% on international account.Long-tail lines while showing flat renewals globally remained the source of considerable concern to us. While the reinsurance market remains discipline, we are heavily impacted by conditions on the direct side where certain sectors of the market remained quite competitive. With that, I'll turn things back to Mike for guidance.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jamie. Before I go on, I was handed a note while my colleagues were speaking that I misstated our book value per share. I gather I said $26.60 when I meant to say $24.60 as you have noticed in the notes. I apologize for any confusion. You should k
componenttext: Thanks, Jamie. Before I go on, I was handed a note while my colleagues were speaking that I misstated our book value per share. I gather I said $26.60 when I meant to say $24.60 as you have noticed in the notes. I apologize for any confusion. You should know, by the way, that the note came from Jacob Rosengarten, our Chief Enterprise Risk Officer, so you know our processes are working well.I will now turn to guidance, I'm sorry for that confusion. You can see from our guidance on Slide 15 of the presentation, we believe we can continue providing solid results even through these difficult conditions that we expect in 2010. All guidance here is subject to the normal caveats, no unusual loss event and the other items you see referenced at the bottom of the guidance slide. To start, we anticipate our gross premiums written in 2010 will be up low-single digits from 2009. You'll notice that net premiums earned may have some catching up to do as they will reflect 2009's lower premiums written. P&C and Corporate net investment income in the range of $800 million to $950 million, reflect both the current low interest rate environment and a level asset base, and our experience management efforts are on track and on time. With all of these elements in place, we believe XL should generate a low double-digit operating ROE in 2010. And now we'll open the lines for your questions.

componenttext: We have seeded a bit less this year, Jay, but basically there's no deep change in our reinsurance purchasing philosophy. What you're seeing mainly is the changing in premium flows into written according to the level of premiums written. And of course our biggest declines were early in the year. Their influence will decline over time in terms of the gap between written and earned.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Again, we've never gotten into the individual components that drive our view of where the year will end. If you want a general answer on capital management, I'm happy to give it now, I'd expect it to come up. I'll give you the standard answer that I've gi
componenttext: Again, we've never gotten into the individual components that drive our view of where the year will end. If you want a general answer on capital management, I'm happy to give it now, I'd expect it to come up. I'll give you the standard answer that I've given now for a number of quarters and really it reflects a philosophy that I've brought to these jobs since I've been in them. And the first most important note, in my view, is the shareholder's money. First, test to how we approach capital management is, do we have adequate capital relative to our ratings, our rating agencies and our own view of the risk we take on. So that's the first thing we focus on. And we think the market would be well aware, we're certainly well aware that we're in a very comfortable position at this point. While we don't get into specific degrees of excess, we obviously are getting very comfortable with our capital position. So once we're in that position, the second thing we look at is, can we put that money to work well given our hurdle return expectations at XL? And then if we can, we put it to work; and if we don't believe we can, then we will return it to shareholders in whatever form we believe is most efficient. That consideration is, those last two, the trade-off between the last two is still ongoing work. And we'll continue to think that through and then we have news that we'll announce.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, Josh, it's Simon Rich. Let me just talk about what we have and we haven't taken here. I mean, I think, looking at the prior year development that we have taken in the over half of that come from the short-tail lines, and we've taken, I would say, a
componenttext: Well, Josh, it's Simon Rich. Let me just talk about what we have and we haven't taken here. I mean, I think, looking at the prior year development that we have taken in the over half of that come from the short-tail lines, and we've taken, I would say, a cautious and a limited view on the longer-tail lines where we have reacted to that. That's really coming from the 2002 to 2006 years. Any years later than that, we just think with all the uncertainties out there, we have to be very careful before we act on that and really on those years, very little to date.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Josh, this is Mike. I would underscore that last point. We have a well-earned reputation for prudence when it comes to reserving. And certainly, I've noted with, I guess, the right word would be interest or whatever in some of the really significant relea
componenttext: Josh, this is Mike. I would underscore that last point. We have a well-earned reputation for prudence when it comes to reserving. And certainly, I've noted with, I guess, the right word would be interest or whatever in some of the really significant releases by some others in the industry in this particular quarter, I would just tell you that our own view is that if we're going to keep that prudence that we're known for, we just think it's at least for our own book and this is not to comment relative that was just for ourselves, but we just think it is too early, given the very noisy economic conditions in which we're living. And given the real specter of inflation, we think it's just too early to react to the very favorable actual reported numbers that we're seeing. So we just think this isn't going to play out to over a bit of time.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2010

componenttext: Our next version comes from Vinay Misquith with Crédit Suisse.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the capital position, I hate to beat a dead horse, but just curious as to whether your share repurchase program is, by any chance, being held up back by these structured investment portfolio? And are you doing anything to get rid of it? You've already
componenttext: On the capital position, I hate to beat a dead horse, but just curious as to whether your share repurchase program is, by any chance, being held up back by these structured investment portfolio? And are you doing anything to get rid of it? You've already saw a lot of it, but I believe you're about 80% through. So just curious about that.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Vinay, this is Mike. No, I wouldn't say that our primary concern, with respect to making decisions around capital management, relates to the investment portfolio at this stage. Certainly, we're mindful that we've just come through a very bumpy period. So
componenttext: Vinay, this is Mike. No, I wouldn't say that our primary concern, with respect to making decisions around capital management, relates to the investment portfolio at this stage. Certainly, we're mindful that we've just come through a very bumpy period. So we believe that caution for the near future is certainly prudent. But it isn't driven by what remains, because we now have that portfolio down so far that we're making the decision that we've emphasized tonight, to shift from de-risking to kind of letting the economics play out as they will. So I think that's an indication of the confidence we have in our capital position, going forward. And as a result, I think the capital management decisions would be made apart from what remains to be done. We'll let time take care of that now, as opposed to the more aggressive mindset that we acted on throughout 2009, and which led us to be able to drive more than $5 billion of such assets off the balance sheet.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: I believe you've mentioned that you have $1 billion or $1.5 billion of the parent company in the form of cash. What's the historical amount that you've had there? And how much is excess capital sitting in company right now?
componenttext: I believe you've mentioned that you have $1 billion or $1.5 billion of the parent company in the form of cash. What's the historical amount that you've had there? And how much is excess capital sitting in company right now?

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Vinay, it's Simon Rich. Just to clarify, what I said is we have $1.5 billion, in terms of cash and investments. We, like many companies, in these times of looking to maintain flexibility, we've actively managed the levels of cash at the parent company ove
componenttext: Vinay, it's Simon Rich. Just to clarify, what I said is we have $1.5 billion, in terms of cash and investments. We, like many companies, in these times of looking to maintain flexibility, we've actively managed the levels of cash at the parent company over the loss, I would say, 18 months to two years. And we are basically in the target zone that we've set for that. Prior to that time, the levels fluctuated a little more.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: My second question is on the investment portfolio. Now that the de-risking is done, are you planning on increasing the risk on your portfolio, especially moving out? I believe you've mentioned something about moving out from government securities to more
componenttext: My second question is on the investment portfolio. Now that the de-risking is done, are you planning on increasing the risk on your portfolio, especially moving out? I believe you've mentioned something about moving out from government securities to more cooperatives. Could you give us a sense for new money yields versus the old money yields?

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Sarah. Certainly, over time, we will be looking to increase --- we're under way to high-quality investment grade credit relative to where we would want to be. And that overweight comes from, we're in government and government related. The new
componenttext: Yes, this is Sarah. Certainly, over time, we will be looking to increase --- we're under way to high-quality investment grade credit relative to where we would want to be. And that overweight comes from, we're in government and government related. The new money yield for the type of investment grade credit that we would want to buy today is about 3%. I would tell you that one of the reasons why we're not rushing in to do it today is that actually, the book yield on the government and government related, given that some those are the securities we bought some time ago, have actually higher book yields on those. So at this point, it doesn't seem to make a lot of sense to us to sell government-guaranteed or government-issued paper to buy lower rated, though high quality, but A, AA-rated paper in return. So that's where we're going to take our time over it.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2010

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: That work is still in progress, and I wouldn't want to comment prematurely on it, except that to say, one of the things that I think is noteworthy, is that on the Life side, it appears that some of the early thinking is, in the Solvency II Life side, it's
componenttext: That work is still in progress, and I wouldn't want to comment prematurely on it, except that to say, one of the things that I think is noteworthy, is that on the Life side, it appears that some of the early thinking is, in the Solvency II Life side, it's a bit more dramatic. Of course, our block there is relatively small, compared to the whole. But that's probably the one place that I've taken more note than anything else. For now, we're still working on getting our internal model accredited, and that's the work that we focus on.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think, Simon, you suggested on the tax issue that the taxes were about $29 million higher than you'd expect. Was that due to just the non-recurring items? Or in general, the higher tax rate, all in?
componenttext: I think, Simon, you suggested on the tax issue that the taxes were about $29 million higher than you'd expect. Was that due to just the non-recurring items? Or in general, the higher tax rate, all in?

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: The $29 million is, I guess, the one-off nature of the items in the quarter. I mean, let me just put some color on that. It's a timely question, given the previous one. Much of the tax came from a reassessment of our year-end reserves, and particularly, I
componenttext: The $29 million is, I guess, the one-off nature of the items in the quarter. I mean, let me just put some color on that. It's a timely question, given the previous one. Much of the tax came from a reassessment of our year-end reserves, and particularly, I guess, we had a higher focus on the level of reserves at a legal entity level, cognizant of our Solvency II risk management efforts and the desire to get the right balance sheet in the right legal entities. In terms of the outcome, what happened was that we ended up having a number of releases in higher tax jurisdictions, and some strengthening in lower tax jurisdictions. And the impact of that was the main part of the $29 million I was referring to. We wouldn't expect to rebalancing of that nature to happen again, and we very much view that as one off.

componenttext: Yes, we will certainly get back to you on that. We, to be honest, are trying to move it towards that we're looking at it on an aggregate basis. So we didn't have the guidance on that basis because we have combined the two together.

So I guess it will be slightly up, but still well under the maximum we established for a potential loss. Let me give Jamie the...

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Now, Matt, I think we've stated, probably before, that our risk appetite for what we call Tier 1 CAT exposure is 15% of shareholders' equity. We have not fully utilized it over the last 18 months. But obviously, that number is going to move, as our balanc
componenttext: Now, Matt, I think we've stated, probably before, that our risk appetite for what we call Tier 1 CAT exposure is 15% of shareholders' equity. We have not fully utilized it over the last 18 months. But obviously, that number is going to move, as our balance sheet changes [ph].

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: I might, Matt, add a little bit more color to Mike's answer around how our exposures changed quite a bit in the last four or five years, certainly since KRW. This is Dave, from insurance. We have reduced our Gulf of Mexico, inland marine and offshore mari
componenttext: I might, Matt, add a little bit more color to Mike's answer around how our exposures changed quite a bit in the last four or five years, certainly since KRW. This is Dave, from insurance. We have reduced our Gulf of Mexico, inland marine and offshore marine exposure by 80%. And we've rid ourselves of one program in particular that where we are writing catastrophe cover, specifically for small commercial, mid-size commercial accounts. So from the insurance perspective, we have effectively reduced a significant portion of our wind exposure, in the most prone area in the U.S., by over 50%.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess the big picture question for you, Mike, is just it feels like you've spent the last -- well, your time at the company may be playing a lot more defense than offense. I guess, now that things seem to be stabilizing from a capital standpoint, and yo
componenttext: I guess the big picture question for you, Mike, is just it feels like you've spent the last -- well, your time at the company may be playing a lot more defense than offense. I guess, now that things seem to be stabilizing from a capital standpoint, and you're through most of the hard work on the portfolio and the business, what are the priorities aside the one that will remain nameless? What are kind of the big strategic priorities you've got that you want to focus on the next 12 to 24 months?

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: The most exciting thing for us is we now get the opportunity to do what we came together to do. I believe that even in these difficult times, meaning relative to the insurance cycles, there are always opportunities for a great underwriting company in XL's
componenttext: The most exciting thing for us is we now get the opportunity to do what we came together to do. I believe that even in these difficult times, meaning relative to the insurance cycles, there are always opportunities for a great underwriting company in XL's history. It has shown it to be one of those. For example, right now, I would point out that we continue to see rate levels that encourage us to selectively write in our professional lines. We see rate levels that continue to encourage us to apply a bit more capital into some of the catastrophe zones. We continue to see rate levels that encourage us in the aviation space. So even though we would cite the overall trends as negative, there are opportunities for us to go out there and sell XL. And that's exactly what we'll be doing. Also, we have kind of an odd opportunity. It's not huge, but it's meaningfully different from what the market is experiencing. And that is, of course, during late 2008 and early 2009 when there were these concerns around XL. There were some counter-parties that chose to cut back their lines, or in even handfuls of extreme cases, not do business with us. Those are people who admire the XL, often did so with, they said, regret. And we're able to go back to them now and say, "Remember how much you love this." And sure enough, we're seeing opportunity get back on lines of business with clients we know very well, and know very well the appropriate rate levels for. And that's a little bit of a lift opportunity for XL that it's kind of oddly gained, but nonetheless, beneficial. So when we look at the marketplace, we see it with probably a little bit more excitement than maybe some do, with who might have different mixes of business or not have that odd little opportunity for lift. As we go through that, what you'll see us doing is continually trying to strengthen the franchise toward being more opportunistic, where there are pockets of real rate opportunity. And that will be true throughout this phase of the cycle, and then aggressively true as we see any sign of turn. We are building our capital, building our expense base and conditioning our people to be ready to take full and appropriate opportunities when that cycle turn comes. So it's about sticking to the soft market playbook in a very aggressive way. It's about keeping real focus where we do have opportunities, and making sure not to leave them on the table. And then, it's about being ready and positioned to take advantage of what comes. Who knows when it will come, but we know it can't last forever, and we know how to get through this kind of period. And so, it gets very exciting for us around here right now. I'll say it one last time, having weathered what we've weathered, we realized, all of us at XL realized the fact that people stuck together. And because our people stuck together, our clients stuck with us, by and large. That just sends a huge message to the marketplace about the resilience of this franchise. And it reveals to us, excess capacity. We not only know we have additional capital, against which we could write. We talked about that earlier. But we also know that, as a company, we have excess capacity as a group of people. Because as that burden receives into the long-ago past, we still have the energy that it left behind. And that energy will be applied to the benefit of our clients, through innovation and through pursuing growth where we think it's opportunistic. So if you were sitting in our places right now, you'd be as excited as we are.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Brian Meredith with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Brian Meredith with UBS.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mike, I was hoping you could give us a little bit of color behind the combined ratio guidance in insurance and reinsurance. Like for instance, with reinsurance, there's a fairly decent drop in the combined ratio, excluding prior-year development from what
componenttext: Mike, I was hoping you could give us a little bit of color behind the combined ratio guidance in insurance and reinsurance. Like for instance, with reinsurance, there's a fairly decent drop in the combined ratio, excluding prior-year development from what we reported this year. And kind of what's your thinking behind that, as well as in the insurance area? What kind of thoughts on loss cost inflation? Kind of how did you come up with these numbers, just generally speaking?

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Broadly, I would tell you that this is the third partial or whole budgeting cycle that I've been through at XL. And each one, I feel we do a better job of getting more and more realistic about where we're starting from, and what opportunities that pretend
componenttext: Broadly, I would tell you that this is the third partial or whole budgeting cycle that I've been through at XL. And each one, I feel we do a better job of getting more and more realistic about where we're starting from, and what opportunities that pretends, given what's going on with trade and loss cost. I'm going to let Dave and Jamie comment specifically on the units. But as I looked at it, and as we, as a collective, reviewed the plans of our various businesses at a much more granular level that we've been able to do during the course of the first couple of years I've been here, I would tell you that I have more confidence of this plan playing out as predicted, than even I did at the beginning of last year. And last year's plan turned out to be somewhere between correct and maybe even a little pessimistic, relative to what really happened. But I'll let Dave start and Jamie follow.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Brian, I guess I'd answer this question in a couple of different ways. First, for the loss ratio standpoint, we feel really good about the position we're in. And as you can see, when you strip out prior year and CAT activity, we have stemmed the developme
componenttext: Brian, I guess I'd answer this question in a couple of different ways. First, for the loss ratio standpoint, we feel really good about the position we're in. And as you can see, when you strip out prior year and CAT activity, we have stemmed the development upwards, in terms of our accident year loss ratios. And that's a result, admittedly in 2009, of no CAT activity, minimal CAT activity. Really no large property losses to speak off. And we didn't have a subprime loan in 2009, which we did have in 2008. Also, that was important to understand as we've got a mix shift, in terms of our business. And as an example, more of our business is written in the professional lines, which earns a stronger ROE. And also underwriting actions. For the last two years, we've been taking tough actions around business that's marginal. And most of that work is now behind us. So from a loss ratio standpoint, we feel pretty good about the fact that we think the loss ratio in 2010 is going to hold steady, as to what we produced in 2009. Now specific to your question about inflation, when you look at all of our lines totaled up, our inflation assumption is just a little bit below 4%. We have not moved that. Keep in mind that we look at that and pay attention to it very carefully. I would draw your attention to the fact that we don't have a lot of more comps, which at this point in time, frankly, we like. We are selectively looking to right comp business. But on a percentage of book basis, it's pretty minimal. And professional, again, is a big chunk of our business. So from a loss ratio standpoint, that gives you a little bit color. The other piece to take into consideration when you think about our combined ratio in 2010, we did a lot of work for the last 18 months. And in addition to some of the work that Mike mentioned at the beginning of 2009, corporate ride around expense reductions. We also did some things specific in this segment that were communicated in the fourth quarter. Our expenses, from year to year, are going to drop materially from 2009 and 2010. That's going to flush through to the combined ratio. So actually, it's a tough market, tough environment. But in terms of how this franchise is positioned, I would echo Mike's comments, we feel a lot better about the position we're in today than we did 12 months ago. And that has nothing to do with the financial crisis issue. So Jamie, for reinsurance?

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Brian, I think there are a couple of pieces in the puzzle you need to bear in mind. One is, as it tends [ph] on the slide, there's no prior-year release assumptions in those numbers. Secondly, we take no joy in shrinking this book of business, but we
componenttext: Yes, Brian, I think there are a couple of pieces in the puzzle you need to bear in mind. One is, as it tends [ph] on the slide, there's no prior-year release assumptions in those numbers. Secondly, we take no joy in shrinking this book of business, but we have been because of the market conditions. And our operating expense ratio, while we've restrained operating expenses, is going up. But I think that probably the biggest element to consider is that, as we have reduced our position in the long-tail markets, property CAT becomes a much bigger percentage of our overall portfolio and has an effect on the loss ratio.

componenttext: And just as far as your PML thresholds, where do they stand right now? Are they still under the, what was it, 15%, 20%? 20%, I guess, to what it was?

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ian Gutterman with Adage Capital.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ian Gutterman with Adage Capital.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: I had a few question on professional liability. I guess, maybe just for context, can you give me a sense of the mix of your book between primary and excess, and also Side A versus other coverages?
componenttext: I had a few question on professional liability. I guess, maybe just for context, can you give me a sense of the mix of your book between primary and excess, and also Side A versus other coverages?

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, Ian. First of all, it's almost evenly split between primary and excess. And that has been historically the case for the last three or four years. I'd also say that our pursuit of FI business is pretty much the same, on a unit or policy basis. It has
componenttext: Sure, Ian. First of all, it's almost evenly split between primary and excess. And that has been historically the case for the last three or four years. I'd also say that our pursuit of FI business is pretty much the same, on a unit or policy basis. It has increased, on a premium basis, in the last two years, primarily, because of the rate we've been able to attract and get from an FI perspective. I would point out though that the FI book, within itself, is well diversified. And maybe, I'll give you a couple of numbers that gives you some perspective, in terms of the global professional book. 42% of it's in D&O, of which 29% is A side only, and this is as of year end 2009; 26% of the book is in E&O; 13% in our design program, architects and engineers; and then we've got about 15%, 20% in a combination of select private and EPL and fiduciary. So we've got good balance for the primary and excess standpoint, a good chunk of our business is A side only and we have a good diversification within the FI class. Ian, I'd also say, one last comment, Ian, I'd also say that we're expanding our presence in Europe, which is an objective. We've got a good position in the U.S., we've built up over the last five or six years. And we're focused on building out our European professional book as well, which will give us more balance from a geographic perspective.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: I understand that sort of the big subprime class action D&O-type suits have still far gone recently well for the industry, and maybe some us are too worried about that as a concern. I guess, my question is I've been hearing more and more about losses in t
componenttext: I understand that sort of the big subprime class action D&O-type suits have still far gone recently well for the industry, and maybe some us are too worried about that as a concern. I guess, my question is I've been hearing more and more about losses in the non-D&O lines from the credit crisis. And not just E&O, but fiduciary. Some of the other banker lines spreading out through other lines. So can you talk about it? Are plaintiffs lawyers trying to find back doors when they're getting the motion to dismiss on the D&O, and they try to find a new way to attack? And is that a concern we should be worried about?

componenttext: It's certainly something to pay attention to, and we're monitoring very closely. I would say that it hasn't materially changed our underwriting appetite. We continue to strive for a pretty good balance between primary and excess. But to your point, we just need to make sure we get the right rate for the excess policy.

componenttext: Yes, sorry. To be perfectly honest, I didn't answer that. What I've said earlier is the number of inputs, the way we look at it, is our job is to give the best assessment we have of where the year will end up. And we've never before know where we get in to getting into specific components of that guidance. As you'll notice, we give a very high level guidance to try and to resist our investors in making their own judgments. But we don't choose to give the kind of precise or detailed judgment that some others do, because we find our business a very difficult one. And we think this is the right way, at least for our comfort, to provide that assistance to our investors.

componenttext: I think, as I've said before, we've been very cautious on recent underwriting years. Of that, only $62 million was for Casualty business. The rest was short-tail business. And we released virtually no prior year reserves for 2008 and fairly modest for 2007. I think we're just being cautious, given some potential macroeconomic issues that some prognosticators are thinking, like inflation.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Alright, listen. We appreciate your being with us tonight. And we know that the shift to doing these calls after hours puts a bit of a strain on everybody, but we can get the information straight to you so that you can do your work. So we hope that's the
componenttext: Alright, listen. We appreciate your being with us tonight. And we know that the shift to doing these calls after hours puts a bit of a strain on everybody, but we can get the information straight to you so that you can do your work. So we hope that's the best way to do. We know you've given us your direct and candid feedback. I would just summarize, we're awfully pleased with where we stand at XL and very excited about where we go next. And I would just offer one last thought. I don't like to bring up the experience at Safeco too much because so much of what we did there is not relevant, and so many of the players and challenges are different. But I can tell you that for the team that worked there, and certainly, for me and I know the team that works here, we don't calculate our success as related to avoiding crisis. We're pleased that we've done so and excited for where we stand. But we really count our success when we are outperforming our competition in various significant ways. And that's what we really strive to do now. That's the next phase of the adventure here in XL. So thanks for your time, and we look forward to delivering on that idea.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would like to welcome everyone to the XL Capital Ltd. first quarter earnings call. (Operator Instructions) I would now like to turn the call over to David Radulski, XL’s Director of Investor Relations.
componenttext: I would like to welcome everyone to the XL Capital Ltd. first quarter earnings call. (Operator Instructions) I would now like to turn the call over to David Radulski, XL’s Director of Investor Relations.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good evening and welcome to XL Capital’s first quarter 2010 earnings conference call. This call is being simultaneously webcast on XL’s website at www.xlcapital.com. We’ve posted to our website several documents including our quarterly financial sup
componenttext:
Good evening and welcome to XL Capital’s first quarter 2010 earnings conference call. This call is being simultaneously webcast on XL’s website at www.xlcapital.com. We’ve posted to our website several documents including our quarterly financial supplement and our fixed income portfolio data. 
On our call today, Mike McGavick, XL Capital’s CEO will offer opening remarks. Simon Rich, our Interim CFO will review our financial results followed by David Duclos, our Chief Executive of Insurance Operations and Jamie Veghte, Chief Executive of ReInsurance operations who will review the segment results and market conditions. Sarah Street, our Chief Investment Officer is with us today and available for Q&A.
Before we begin, I’d like to remind you that certain of the matters we’ll discuss today are forward-looking statements. These statements are based on current plans, estimates and expectations. Forward-looking statements involve inherent risks and uncertainties and a number of factors could cause actual results to differ materially from those contained in the forward-looking statements, and therefore you should not place undue reliance on them.
Forward-looking statements are sensitive to many factors including those identified in our annual report on Form 10-K, our quarterly reports on Form 10-Q and other documents on file with the SEC that could cause actual results to differ materially from those contained in the forward-looking statements. 
Forward-looking statements speak only as of the date on which they are made and we undertake no obligation publicly to revise any forward-looking statement in response to new information, future developments or otherwise.
And with that, I’ll turn it over to Mike McGavick.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good evening. I’m pleased to report to you another quarter of solid operating results even as the global P&C industry experienced some of its worst quarter one-cat events ever. Our nearly break even P&C combined ratio of 100.5 included a 14.3 points fro
componenttext:
Good evening. I’m pleased to report to you another quarter of solid operating results even as the global P&C industry experienced some of its worst quarter one-cat events ever. Our nearly break even P&C combined ratio of 100.5 included a 14.3 points from the Chilean earthquake and storm Xynthia as our estimates from these losses from these two events remains within the preliminary range we published in March.
We did see some offsets against these caps with 6.9 point of positive prior year development, mostly from short sale property lines in both Insurance and ReInsurance. For the fourth consecutive quarter, we grew out book value for ordinary share, this time another 7% to $26.38 and by 8% intangible book value per share to $23.92, and total shareholders’ equity increased from $9.4 billion to $10 billion.
The first quarter caps impact on operating income and the continued increase in our shareholders equity resulted in annualized operating ROE of 6.9% for the first quarter. Without the impact of the two named cats, our operating ROE would have been 14.2%.
We see these results as an endorsement of our continued discipline in both underwriting and risk management, and I’ve said before, and I’ll say it again, perhaps as much for the benefit of any XL underwriters who are listening in, XL will not write coverage at uneconomic price levels.
So while we grew our P&C top line by 2.3% year over year, much of that growth, as we had anticipated and predicted at the beginning of the  year, came from lines we found attractive, including aerospace, cat and DNO as well as several long time customers returning to XL. We welcomed them back.
Meanwhile, we continue to lower our premiums written for multi-year Insurance premiums and from uneconomic businesses such as casualty, factory and Insurance that we exited last year. 
It was a quiet quarter for our investment portfolio, which is looking more like the P&C portfolio should, as our optimization program continues. And while we saw the benefit of a $522 million in favorable marks to market this quarter, I should remind you that what goes up goes down and as interest rates can rise or fall, we’ll just have to see what happens next.
We do know that our excellent liquidity and well-matched asset liability profile will let us ride out any interest rate volatility.
On a risk management note, in March of 2009 we instructed our portfolio managers, and here I guess I’m more in line with current news, I instructed our managers back in March of 2009 to stop purchasing sovereign debt from Greece and Ireland and severely restricted exposures to the debt of Portugal, Italy and Spain.
So our cumulative exposure to sovereign debt from these five countries is down to approximately $34 million or less than one tenth of one percent of our entire investment portfolio, including no exposure to Greece.
Likewise, we made significant progress on another risk management initiative. Last week, as you well know, our ordinary shareholders approved several proposals, most notably our change of parent domicile from the Cayman Islands to Ireland.
There are several more conditions to satisfy before this move will be complete, but shareholder approval was a significant move in the right direction, and we thank our shareholders for supporting the recommendations of management and the Board.
Also in current news, as you noticed in our release yesterday, we are very pleased to announce that Irene Esteves has agreed to join XL as our Chief Financial Officer. She is a deeply experienced business leader and we’re delighted to have her on our team. Irene joins us on May 17.
You can also look forward to the release of our global loss triangles this week. Now I’ll finish my remarks on the first quarter by saying that XL is once again firing on all cylinders in a very difficult market condition. 
Our underlying P&C results are solid and showing positive trends. Our risk management efforts are proving out and our organization, we believe, is getting stronger by the day. While the entire P&C faces challenges deploying capital in this kind of pricing environment, we believe we can build on XL’s success by providing our brokers and customers with the coverage’s they value and the service they demand.
Before I turn it over to Simon, I should comment on the terrible events in the Gulf of Mexico. Like anyone on this call, we deeply mourn the loss of life and we’re all watching with horror the continuing and likely environmental damage. 
It’s much too early to know what the insurable losses are on a total basis, and what portion of these losses XL might cover, but we can say this. We believe that our total property damage exposure to the rig itself is approximately $30 million including $5 million in reinstatement premiums and we have in fact, already paid much of this in claims. For what it’s worth, that would equate to a roughly $900 million industry event.
Now as I hand it over to Simon, I would like to thank him publicly for his outstanding service as XL’s interim CFO since the first of the year. Thanks Simon, and on to you.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks Mike, and good evening. Before I comment on the results of the quarter, I wanted to take a moment to expand on the comment in our press release on our calculation of operating income.We manage foreign exchange volatility from an economic perspect
componenttext:
Thanks Mike, and good evening. Before I comment on the results of the quarter, I wanted to take a moment to expand on the comment in our press release on our calculation of operating income.
We manage foreign exchange volatility from an economic perspective through the matching of assets and liabilities. However, GAAP provides an asymmetrical treatment for the movement of assets and liabilities with the results of a foreign exchange gain or loss in the income statement really doesn’t represent any underlying economics.
We’ve discussed this with a number of you and what you’ve told us is that you too, really don’t find it a relevant indicator of performance. Accordingly, we’ve decided that we will no longer include foreign exchange gains and losses within our operating income, and we’ve represented prior periods on a consistent basis.
Page 30 of our financial supplements shows the operating income for each of the quarters since the first quarter of 2009 on this new basis. And now to the results themselves.
Operating income for the quarter was $150 million or $0.44 per ordinary share with an annualized operation ROE of 6.9%. This compares to $191 million , $0.57 per ordinary share and 14.9% respectively in the prior year quarter.
Turning to our summary financial results on Slide 4, P&C gross premiums written were up by 2.3% from the prior year quarter, reflecting targeted new business growth including the recapture of certain business lost in 2009, and $15 million more of non catastrophe related reinstatement premiums than in the prior year quarter.
P&C net premiums written increased by 6.1% reflecting a reduction in the levels of seeded premium in the quarter. I would say that part of this is a timing difference and we expect some $25 million of ReInsurance purchases that would otherwise have been made in the first quarter to occur in later quarters this year.
P&C net premiums were down 4.4% in the first quarter compared to the first quarter of 2009. This reflects the rolling effects of prior period’s lower written premium. The P&C combined ratio for the first quarter of 100.5% shows the effect of first quarter cats of $181 million, which as set out on Slide 5, added 14.3 points to the loss ratio for the quarter.
This was offset in part by favorable prior year development of $87 million, which is line with the $90 million recognized in the prior year quarter. In the current quarter, $72 million of the releases were from short tail lines.
Our underlying combined ratio excluding prior year development and natural catastrophe’s was 93.1%, 3.8 points better than the prior year quarter. This improvement reflects the restructuring costs in the first quarter of 2009, changes in our business mix and the benefits of the higher non-catastrophe reinstatement premiums I referred to earlier.
Investment income on the P&C portfolio decreased in Q1 compared to the prior year quarter. This was due to lower portfolio yield, driven by the decline in LIBOR, combined with high concentrations of cash and governments as we move towards a portfolio that’s more typical of a P&C insurer.
During the quarter, we put new money to work largely in investment grade credit, achieving an average rate of 3.2% and as a result P&C’s duration increased marginally to three years. At March 31, 2010, the P&C portfolio book yield gross of fees, was 3.6%.
As a result of recent developments in certain European government markets, we’ve added additional disclosures to our fixed income supplement. As you can see, within the Euro zone, 94% of our government holdings are in France and Germany. 
At $229 million of operating expenses for the quarter, with $39 million or 15% lower year over year. The reduction arises principally from the fact that we incurred some $40 million of restructuring costs in the prior year quarter, with this reduction offset in part by $6 million of higher reported expenses arising from foreign exchange rate fluctuations.
In the first quarter, we recognized a gain to ordinary shareholders of $16.6 million from the further repurchase of Series C preference shares and now the remaining par value outstanding of those shares is only $71.9 million.
The main drivers of our 7% growth in book value per ordinary share were operating earnings and the favorable mark to market of $522 million during the quarter. This arose from tightening credit spreads and from lower interest rates, and as set out on Slide 3, we ended the first quarter with over $12.5 billion in total capital, an increase of over 4% in the quarter.
Now over to David.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Insurance segment results for the first quarter were strong considering the impact of Q1 cats including most notably the Chilean earthquake. Our combined ratio of 101.6% for the quarter was 2.7 points higher than our Q1 2009 results of 98.9%, which had be
componenttext:
Insurance segment results for the first quarter were strong considering the impact of Q1 cats including most notably the Chilean earthquake. Our combined ratio of 101.6% for the quarter was 2.7 points higher than our Q1 2009 results of 98.9%, which had been favorably impacted by limited cat activity. Adjusting for both cat and prior year development, the Insurance segment’s 2010 combined ratio of 96.4% was 2.7 points better than the same period last year.
Gross premiums written in Q1 increased 3.7% or $41 million year over year. We are fully aware of the difficult trading environment, and I can assure you that we are in no way relaxing our underwriting discipline. Our growth was led by selected business wins and increased participation in attractive lines including professional, marine, upper middle market and aviation.
As Mike mentioned, it also included some significant win backs in several lines including professional, which is particularly rewarding. Net premiums earned were down just over 1% or $13 million as we recognized the anticipated earn through of last year’s lower gross premiums written.
On the loss side, Q1 cat losses were partially offset by some favorable prior year development largely in our short tail lines.  Our Q1 2010 loss ratio was 72.3% compares to 67.6% last year. However, when adjusted for both cats and prior year development, our underlying loss rate ratio is slightly better year over year at 67.1% versus 67.85. This was driven primarily by a lack of property losses, exiting less attractive businesses and the related shift in business mix.
Acquisition expenses were up slightly, reflecting modestly higher brokerage commissions in some line as well as a change in our business mix to lines such as professional and specialty that have always had higher brokerage commission structures.
This was partially offset by reduced operating expenses as our previously announced expense and organizational initiatives took hold. Total expense ratio for Q1 2010 of 29.3% was two points lower than Q1 2009.
Before I move on to market conditions, let me provide a couple of comments on our Professional book and why our profitability outlook remains in line with expectations. First, we saw lower than expected claims activity during the first quarter in our core professional book as the overall industry SEC class action frequency was lower than for the same period of 2009.
Second, various financial crisis related matters from the 2007 and 2008 period developed favorably for XL along with the rest of the DNO industry during the quarter. As a result, we remain comfortable with our initial valuation of XL’s financial crisis exposure and the reserves we hold against it.
Regarding the market, despite the challenging macro economic conditions faced by many of our clients we continue to see clear and steady improvements in both retentions and new business submissions throughout our book. Our premium retentions for the first quarter were just over 85% on a segment basis, significantly better than the low 70’s experienced in Q1 2009. We are now back on track for historical retention levels.
What does give us concern is broad market pricing. After three quarters of modest increases of plus 1% and plus 2%, we saw some give back as our overall pricing declined 1% for the first quarter, slightly better than the Q1 2009 decline of 1.6%. We saw this reflected across most lines, with the only notable pricing increases recorded in our specialty book.
While we recognize the challenging market, we continue to build on our Insurance foundations of underwriting and claims bank. We successfully recruited two market leaders, [Zarana Mogg] and Patrick Tannic to join our team. Zarana will be joining us as Chief Executive of our North America P&C unit and Patrick is already on board as our Bermuda country manager. Welcome.
Operationally we turned the switch on our new centralized global claims management system in the U.S., Canada and Bermuda. We see improved customer service, faster response, and lower cost as only three of the benefits of this upgrade. We intend to expand the system throughout South American, Europe and Asia next year.
XL is approaching 2010 much as we finished 2009. We continue to renew existing books of business where rates are acceptable. We’re selectively writing new business at the right price, and we continue taking necessary actions to lower our expenses, all while remaining disciplined in our underwriting and engage with our brokers and clients.
I’ll finish with some observations we made at RIMS, which was held in Boston last week. XL hosted over 225 client meetings at RIMS and we heard time and again what they were looking for; a lead writer than can provide existing and new products and services supported by solid risk engineering, a clear history of claims performance and a global presence, all supported by a solid capital foundation. It was reassuring to hear that what they want, we can provide.
And now to Jamie to discuss ReInsurance.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks David and good evening. XL RE also enjoyed a positive quarter in difficult market conditions and significant levels of natural catastrophe activity. Our underwriting results for the quarter were good with a combined ratio of 97.8% resulting in an u
componenttext:
Thanks David and good evening. XL RE also enjoyed a positive quarter in difficult market conditions and significant levels of natural catastrophe activity. Our underwriting results for the quarter were good with a combined ratio of 97.8% resulting in an underwriting profit of $8.1 million. This compares with a combined ratio of 77.2% in Q1 of 2009.
Embedded in these results were losses of $81.6 million and $19.9 million from the Chilean earthquake and windstorm Xynthia respectively. The result also included positive prior year reserve releases of $53.8 million.
Adjusting for cat losses and prior year releases, the segment had a combined ratio of 84.8%, a seven point improvement over the first quarter of 2009. This improvement was driven by 3.5 points on the expense ratio related to our U.S. crop portfolio, acquisition, the cost of adjustments in Bermuda and Europe and non-recurring severance charges from the first quarter of 2009.
The loss ratio also had a 3.5 point improvement driven by the benefit of reinstatement premiums in Europe on non property business and a mix of business impact on property increase proportionately and a decrease in our trade credit business.
Turning to top line gross net premiums written were $790 million and $695 million respectively, basically flat year over year growth and a 3% increase net driven by reduced sessions on our multi-carrier crop portfolio.
Finally, turning tour Life Operations, contribution during the quarter was $49 million. This included a one-time gain of $13.8 million as a result of three treaties being commuted with clients.
I’d like to comment briefly on the Chilean earthquake before turning to market conditions. While it’s still early, and we are relying heavily on model results to establish our net loss estimate, we feel very good about our performance in this event. Our Latin American business unit contributed $66 million of the $82 million total loss to the segment with the remainder emanating from Bermuda and our London retro book.
Based on our estimate market share as published by the Superintendant of Insurance in Chile and assuming an industry loss of $6 billion to $8 billion, which we believe to be the case, our net loss is well below what peer market share analysis would indicate. This is principally due to fairly aggressive use of what I would describe as spot retrocession purchasing in the region.
The distribution of this loss into the industry with perhaps upwards of 80% to 90% into the ReInsurance market, is reflective of some broader issues in emerging markets we believe need to be addressed by the industry. This would include heavy reliance on proportional Insurance, event or asses the limits on these structures at levels that make them virtually meaningless, inadequate underlying rate levels and commission structures that do not allow sufficient margin to fund events of this magnitude.
While the event will obviously provide the market with an opportunity to address underlying rate adequacy, we will also advocate significant structural change in the market, principally a reliance on non proportional ReInsurance, our preferred product.
As we’ve mentioned in our last few calls, market conditions remain challenging. We’ve kept our top line flat due principally to recaptured business that was lost at year end 2008 and selected new opportunities, mostly in Europe.
We are broadly concerned about market conditions however. For example, our Japanese cap portfolio jus turned over April 1, with a risk adjusted reduction in pricing of 5.5%. This is in a market that clearly needed more rate as we entered the renewal, and as a result, we reduced our position in this very important market yet again.
On the long tail side as David mentioned, there is broad competition across the market although we do see pockets of positive in some areas of the professional lines and U.K. for example. Overall, we’re very pleased with our underwriting performance against this backdrop and we will continue to be vigilant with our underwriting as this phase of the market plays itself out.
With that, I will turn it back to David for Q&A.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
