headline: XL Group plc, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. My name is Shirley, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the XL Group plc Third Quarter Earnings Call. All lines have been placed on mute to prevent any background noise. After the
componenttext:
Good afternoon. My name is Shirley, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the XL Group plc Third Quarter Earnings Call. All lines have been placed on mute to prevent any background noise. After the speaker’s remarks, there will be a question-and-answer session. Please be advised this conference is being recorded.
I would now like to turn the call over to David Radulski, XL Director of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: XL Group plc, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Shirley. Good evening. And welcome to XL Group’s third quarter 2010 conference call. This call is being simultaneously webcast on XL’s website at www.xlgroup.com. We posted to our website several documents including our quarterly financial
componenttext:
Thank you, Shirley. Good evening. And welcome to XL Group’s third quarter 2010 conference call. This call is being simultaneously webcast on XL’s website at www.xlgroup.com. We posted to our website several documents including our quarterly financial supplement and our fixed income portfolio data.
On our call today, Mike McGavick, XL Group CEO will offer opening remarks; Irene Esteves, our CFO will review financial results followed by Dave Duclos, our Chief Executive of Insurance Operations; and Jamie Veghte, our Chief Executive of Reinsurance Operations, who will review the segment results and market conditions, and then we’ll open it up for questions. Sarah Street, our Chief Investment Officer is with us today and available for Q&A.
Before we begin, I’d like to remind you that certain of the matters we’ll discuss today are forward-looking statements. These statements are based on current plans, estimates and expectations. Forward-looking statements involve inherent risks and uncertainties, and a number of factors could cause actual results to differ materially from those contained in the forward-looking statements and therefore you should not place undue reliance on them.
Forward looking statements are sensitive to many factors including those identified in our annual report on Form 10-K, our quarterly reports on Form 10-Q, and other documents on file with the SEC, that could cause actual results to differ materially from those contained in the forward-looking statements. Forward-looking statements speak only as of the date on which they are made and we undertake no obligation publicly to revise any forward-looking statements in response to new information, future development or otherwise.
And with that, I turn it over to Mike McGavick.

headline: XL Group plc, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good evening. Our third quarter results reflect continued solid performance offset by an unusual number of unrelated larger losses. But to give weight to my view on our strong underlying results, I would point to the fact that our overall P&C loss ratio o
componenttext:
Good evening. Our third quarter results reflect continued solid performance offset by an unusual number of unrelated larger losses. But to give weight to my view on our strong underlying results, I would point to the fact that our overall P&C loss ratio of 64% barely moved year-over-year, despite these difficult and soft market conditions and our reinsurance segment had another terrific quarter with a loss ratio of 43% and a combined ratio of 75%.
At the same time, this is a quarter in which our earnings were affected by an unusual number of smaller catastrophes and large losses, such as the New Zealand earthquake, floods in Germany and higher frequency of other news worthy loss events.
As I have mentioned in my previous calls, by the nature of XL’s global footprint and the large limits and complex risk XL takes on, this kind of lumpiness will happen from time-to-time. Importantly, after review, these losses were consistent with our risk management and underwriting standards.
Prior year reserve development was again a strong contributor in the quarter and while these benefits of past reserving actions are realized, we continue to exercise the disciplined approach to establishing current reserve levels.
In reinsurance, we had an $86.8 million in a positive prior year development and in insurance we had a $4.5 million reserve strengthening. But let me point out, that in the third quarter is not one in which we do a deep review of some of the lines in insurance that have been among our best performing recently.
The fourth quarter will affect a more comprehensive review of all of our product lines so stay tuned. As we again -- and we again delivered strong book value per share growth for the sixth straight quarter this time by 6.6% on a fully diluted basis. Our growth in book value was driven primarily by the positive impact on investment portfolio mark-to-market of lower U.S. and U.K. interest rates.
You may recall at the beginning of the year we forecast a low double-digit ROE for the year, since then, between the caps that hit earlier in the year combined with the exceptional strengthening of our balance sheet in the year-to-date have held our operating ROE in the single digits.
Likewise at the beginning of the year, we forecast we might be able to incur some growth in our P&C gross written premiums, but as the markets have developed of course, the competition has intensified and our view, for example, I would point out that aviation might have had the shortest hard market in history, and so, our view now as we look forward to the end of the year is -- it might be flat or slightly down in terms of total gross written premium. This current market pricing makes it unlikely that we would meet that top goal that we have laid out. Our underwriters are simply putting down them.
Since there are currently fewer acceptable places to put your money work however, we have begin -- back to shareholders. We started buying back shares in August, since then have bought back $375 million worth of shares and reduced our Q2 2010 share count by 5.5%. And with that authorization or exhausted our Board of Directors authorized an additional $1 billion share buyback program.
As I have said consistently our first priority is to put any excess capital to invest in our core business. But if there are no viable options to do that we will return our capital to shareholders. You can be assure that this deal is still the case.
Now, let me turn it over to Irene to discuss our financial results.

headline: XL Group plc, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike, and good evening. Turning to our summary financial results on slide four, P&C gross premiums written for the third quarter 2010 were down 3.7% year-over-year. As Mike mentioned, this reflects our disciplined underwriting in the current soft
componenttext:
Thanks, Mike, and good evening. Turning to our summary financial results on slide four, P&C gross premiums written for the third quarter 2010 were down 3.7% year-over-year. As Mike mentioned, this reflects our disciplined underwriting in the current soft pricing environment, including a limited appetite for viewing long-term business.
For example, accelerated premiums from insurance long-term agreements were down $24 million versus the same quarter last year. P&C net premiums written were down 2.4% versus the third quarter of 2009 with an increase of 3.3% in reinsurance offset by a decrease of 5.1% in the insurance segment.
P&C net premiums earned fell by 1.9%, primarily due to the rolling effects of prior periods lower premiums written. Prior year development in the quarter was a favorable $82.3 million or 6.5 loss ratio points. This reflects favorable development in the reinsurance segment, partially offset by small amount of strengthening in the insurance segment.
To put this in perspective, it is important to keep in mind how our reserving process works. Q3 is what we refer to as an actual versus expected or A versus E quarter for our insurance segment and the U.S. reinsurance business. Since we do our detailed roundup reserve reviews in the second and fourth quarters with the interim quarters based on actual versus expected, you would generally not expect to see much movement in prior year reserves in the first and third quarters for these portions of our business which account for 80% of our reserves.
In the A versus E reviews, we respond to movements in the shorter tail lines or to specific claim movements in older mature years and that’s what you see this quarter. With the $4 million strengthening in insurance relating primarily to specific property claims activity. The remaining 20% of our reserves are dominated by non-U.S. casualty and shorter tail reinsurance business for which reserves are reviewed quarterly with more comprehensive assumption updates performed annually.
This business is the source of a favorable development this quarter in reinsurance. These releases were somewhat higher than previous quarters due to favorable development in two specific areas. The processing of reinsurance to close of several whole account contracts from the 2000 year of account contributed $30 million in reserve releases and favorable developments on specific professional liability claims in the 2001 and 2002 report years contributed $25 million. The remaining favorable development for reinsurance was spread across all classes and all non-U.S. geographies.
Our $236 million of operating expenses for the third quarter of 2010 were basically flat year-over-year but expenses for the first three quarters of 2010 were down 7.4% versus the first three quarters of 2009, reflecting the run rate benefits from our prior expense management initiative. Operating income for the third quarter was $175 million or $0.52 per ordinary share with an annualized operating ROE of 7.2%.
Now turning to slide five, our investment income on the P&C portfolio of $218 million, decreased by 8% in the third quarter, compared to the prior year quarter. This was primarily due to the lower portfolio yields driven by lower U.S. interest rates. New purchases were mainly in high quality investment grade corporate credit. The average new investment rate was 2.3%, reflecting the lower absolute rate levels we are currently facing.
Our P&C duration was stable from the prior quarter at 2.7 years and during the quarter the P&C portfolio book yield net of fees was 3.14%. As of quarter end, the gross book yield on the P&C portfolio was 3.5%.
As of September 30th, the total of $2.8 billion from our Life books investment portfolio was designated as held to maturity and reduced the interest rate sensitivity of our GAAP based book value by approximately $300 million for every 100 basis point parallel interest rate change in the euro and sterling markets.
There was a favorable $436 million mark-to-market in the third quarter, driven by lower interest rates on U.S. and U.K. securities and modest spread tightening. This has brought our entire available for sale portfolio into a net unrealized gain position of $157 million and our total portfolio to a net gain position of $236 million after tax. Net income from investment fund affiliates was down substantially from last year due to challenging market conditions for alternative managers, compared to an exceptional result last year this quarter.
Now turning to slide six, the largest contributor to our third quarter growth in book value per share was $1.39 per share change in unrealized gains on investments. Our share buyback activity in Q3 added another $0.41 per share.
Since the beginning of the third quarter to date, we have purchased 18.8 million shares at an average cost of $19.95 for a total of $375 million. During Q3, we repurchased 13.9 million shares at an average cost of $19.33. We purchased another 4.9 million shares after the quarter close. At the end of the second quarter we started -- we have 342 million ordinary shares outstanding. At the end of the third quarter we had 328 million and as of today there’s approximately 323 million shares.
As Mike mentioned, we also announced in our release this afternoon that our Board has authorized another $1 billion worth of share buybacks. Our timing if and when we buyback shares will be driven by market conditions.
Please note that we also recognized $0.45 per share dilutive effect during the quarter. This was caused principally by our 2011 equity security units or ESUs moving into the money, as our share price rose above the price threshold of $18.88 for those units. I would remind you that XL will issue a maximum of just over 30.4 million shares in August 2011 in connection with these units.
With all of these changes, we ended up the third quarter with $29.56 book value per share, up $0.07 -- 7% from Q2 and up 20% from the beginning of the year.
With that, let me turn it over to Dave Duclos to review our insurance business.

headline: XL Group plc, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Irene. XL ensures again specialized in complex risks. From time-to-time we have quarters where our results are impacted by large non-cat losses. We last had this occur six quarters ago and it happened again in Q3 2010 as we had large property loss
componenttext:
Thanks, Irene. XL ensures again specialized in complex risks. From time-to-time we have quarters where our results are impacted by large non-cat losses. We last had this occur six quarters ago and it happened again in Q3 2010 as we had large property losses, excess casualty and aviation losses. This is to be expected given the nature of our business.
The combined ratio for the quarter of 104% was 5.4 points higher than our Q3 2009 results of 98.6%. Adjusting for both cats and prior year development the segments Q3 combined ratio of 100.6% was 2.7 points higher than the prior result of 27.9%. The cat impact in this years third quarter result was 2.8 points as compared to a prior year cat impact of 1.7 points, driven by the New Zealand earthquake and the German floods. Our net cat loss in the quarter was $25 million.
On the loss side, the large non-cat loss I previously mentioned impacted our results by $36 million. While these losses negatively impacted the quarter, our year-to-date accident year loss ratio ex-cats the 68.1% was actually slightly better than the prior year ratio of 69.5%.
This loss ratio improvement was due to a mix of business changes offsetting rate reduction, as well as the favorable impact from a financial line contract, which benefited the current year loss ratio by 1.8 points and year-to-date by 0.6 points.
Gross premiums written in Q3 decreased 3% or $30 million. Excluding the impacts of foreign exchange premiums decreased 1.6%. Considering the challenging trading environment we find ourselves in we consider this an appropriate result given our focus on maintaining our underwriting discipline.
Net premiums earn were down 3.7% or $33 million, largely reflecting the earn-through of lower gross premiums written. As we have commented on in the past, we continue to remain confident in the adequacy of our reserves related to the financial crisis exposure.
Although, D&O claim trends and favorable developments of various financial crisis related matters from the 2007 and 2008 period might suggest to some a bit of conservatism on our part. The most recent financial institution developments serve as an example as to why a careful and cautious view is appropriate. Here, again, we are carefully monitoring and analyzing the financial institution situation to gauge the impact, if any, on our D&O and E&O books of business.
I expect my comments regarding market conditions won’t be surprise any of you. It’s a theme that you are hearing pretty consistently. Competition for business has gotten more intense in many areas and it’s clear that there’s an abundance of capital at work fighting for a shrinking insurance dollar.
The market is not headed in the right direction in the recent quarters pricing results with some lines in geographies at pre 9/11 pricing levels. Well, our retention and submission flow are at or better than expected in most of our businesses, soft pricing means we have decided to write less new business than we did last year.
That said, we continue to pursue selective growth initiatives including expansion into the Asian markets, build out of our European professional book, our U.S. and global general aviation initiative, as well as several other opportunities that are various stages of analysis and implementation like the new North America construction practice.
We are staying disciplined and focusing on where we can improve profit while positioning our business for growth, especially as it relates to distribution and network development, operational efficiency, emerging markets and expanding our product suite.
And now to Jamie to discuss reinsurance.

headline: XL Group plc, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dave, and good morning. XL re-enjoyed another very strong quarter of underwriting results in challenging market conditions. During the period, we achieved a combined ratio of 75% resulting in an underwriting profit of $99.1 million. This compares
componenttext:
Thanks, Dave, and good morning. XL re-enjoyed another very strong quarter of underwriting results in challenging market conditions. During the period, we achieved a combined ratio of 75% resulting in an underwriting profit of $99.1 million. This compares to a combined ratio of 80.5% in the third quarter of 2009. Our results this quarter included positive prior year reserve development of $86.8 million, which compares to releases of $65.9 million in the third quarter of last year.
Adjusting for both cat losses and prior year releases, this segment had a combined ratio of 86.5%, which compares favorably to the 93.4% achieved in the third quarter of last year. The largest components of this improvement were reduced attritional property losses in our U.S. business unit representing 2.8 loss ratio points and a reduction in losses from our old structured product unit, representing 2.2 points and some business mix changes.
Turning to topline, gross net premiums written were $534 million and $389 million, respectively, a reduction of 5% on the gross and an increase of on the net of 3.3%. The reduction in the gross book came principally from the Bermuda and U.S. operations, and resulted from reductions on new and renewal business, some timing differences in Bermuda, and reduction in our U.S. crop portfolio. On the net side, the increase resulted from reduced sessions on this crop portfolio.
Finally, with respect to our Life operation the contribution during the quarter was $20.7 million, essentially flat from the third quarter of last year.
Turning to the market, we commented on the July 1 renewals on our last earnings call. In a nutshell cat market pricing was off 10% on a risk adjusted basis in the U.S. and 5% internationally. Long tail lines remain a significant challenge other than in very specific pockets of opportunity. Otherwise, the quarter was as usual, a quiet one for reinsurance business activity.
We have spent a significant amount of time with customers and brokers at various conferences such as Monte Carlo, PCI and CIAB. These discussions have been very encouraging relative to our franchise and in many long-term business relationships we have established over the years.
Nevertheless, there is clearly an expectation that competitive trading conditions will continue for some time in most sectors of the market. We are confident that the quality of our portfolio and our analytical capabilities will serve us well in these conditions. We believe this is an underwriters’ market and we will continue to exert discipline in our activities as we prepare for our year-end renewals.
With that, I’ll turn it back to David for Q & A.

componenttext:
Yeah. Josh, that contract was a multiyear contract that we had established a premium deficiency reserve. And essentially when the underlying exposures fell below the attachment point of our contract, basically there’s no more exposure to our contract and we were able to release that premium deficiency reserve. So as we did that -- that went through the net incurred loss line and it’s considered current year loss activity. So there was a benefit due to that release of the premium deficiency reserve and that’s considered current year.
There was also some unearned premium associated with that contract and that premium was earned in the quarter. And that net impact of both of those actions, the loss reserve and the premium had a beneficial impact on the current year loss ratio.

headline: XL Group plc, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: As you know, Keith, when you get to this phase of the market the competition lights up across the Board. You’re going to see it in price, you’ll see it in terms and conditions, you’ll see a lot of pressure from multiyear contracts. So you’ll see i
componenttext:
As you know, Keith, when you get to this phase of the market the competition lights up across the Board. You’re going to see it in price, you’ll see it in terms and conditions, you’ll see a lot of pressure from multiyear contracts. So you’ll see it in every aspect.
Our job as underwriters is to try and come up with solutions that work for our clients but still work for us and the net effect of that entire set of influences has us seeing our topline become more challenging to come by, which we’re fine with, because we won’t let our underwriters give it away.
So, but you’ll see negotiations across every dimension of that. And again, our job is to try and find a combination of solutions that works. Yeah, we started walking away from multiyear contracts. I can remember talking about this back a year ago. So we try to defend our position and get the answers that work for both clients and ourselves.

componenttext: Keith, this is Dave Duclos and no, we’re not. And I would also say that to amplify Mike’s comments, the market use of that has actually picked up in the last couple of quarters, for whatever reason I don’t understand given where pricing’s at. But the two things that we’re seeing most in a couple of our lines business, is the reemergence of long-term agreements and also on a property basis, folks just throwing in top side limits. And as Mike said, we are not playing that game and it’s having an effect a bit on both retention as well as business activity.

And then the second question just regarding the ROE overall of the franchise, I think it’s pretty obvious from the share repurchase that you can do, that you can decrease the denominator to get that move, but is there any opportunity, for margins within the business, specific to excel, we know pricing is difficult but anything specific to you guys that we should be thing about?

headline: XL Group plc, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the thing that we would emphasize is that we did take a number of that underwriting actions over the last year and year and half and that is slowly remixing our book of business that’s one of the reason that we are able to keep the loss ration ove
componenttext:
Well, the thing that we would emphasize is that we did take a number of that underwriting actions over the last year and year and half and that is slowly remixing our book of business that’s one of the reason that we are able to keep the loss ration over the period fairly flat despite the deterioration in pricing out there. So you are going to see that effect continue because those performing books continue to role off and have less influence.
At the same time we do have some lines of business well we are thrilled by the results and we are still find them adequate in and so in those lines we continue to be able to write some new business to offset the impact of the loss business from the discipline underwriting. So we have some pockets where we are okay with that and we can keep writing the business. We are continue to have an impact from the re-underwriting actions and those will continue to roll up and net of that is that so far tightened hard we can able to keep our loss ration fairly flat.

componenttext: Fair enough. The second question on the ESUs, the $575 million of debt, are the rating agencies right now already granting the company equity credit for that? And once these are up for conversion do you plan to remarket the debt and use the debt again to buy back more stock in addition to the $1 billion that you have right now?

headline: XL Group plc, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: We currently are planning to remarket the debt but we have a number of options as far as our leverage and debt coming due over the next 15 months and we’ll review the market at that time and make those decisions. The decision to buy back additional shar
componenttext: We currently are planning to remarket the debt but we have a number of options as far as our leverage and debt coming due over the next 15 months and we’ll review the market at that time and make those decisions. The decision to buy back additional shares as we’ve said has more to do with how we feel about our excess capital, what our other alternatives are for the capital and what the market is at that point in time.

headline: XL Group plc, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I go back to what I’ve been saying consistently on these calls, I guess, really for two years although there were times, I guess when it was less relevant than it is now but the reality is our first test is not only do we meet our regulatory and rating
componenttext:
I go back to what I’ve been saying consistently on these calls, I guess, really for two years although there were times, I guess when it was less relevant than it is now but the reality is our first test is not only do we meet our regulatory and rating agency the capital requirements but also with a buffer that gives us comfort for operating the business. Once we have that taken care of then we do look at what’s left over after we’ve satisfied those things and our first objective is to improve the franchise, strengthen the franchise and we do look for opportunities that would meet our long-range hurdles.
And when we’re not excited by anything we see then we turn to giving this capital back to our shareholders, through as we have in this case, share repurchases. That same process will be an active process and an ongoing process and as periodically we evaluate those three factors and as Irene indicated where the market is we’ll make our adjustments accordingly. There’s no change in this approach at all.

headline: XL Group plc, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Are the kinds of business that you may be interested in any different than they were, I think you talked about actually [mutual fund] in the past and some other type of businesses.
componenttext: Are the kinds of business that you may be interested in any different than they were, I think you talked about actually [mutual fund] in the past and some other type of businesses.

headline: XL Group plc, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we’ve talked about a lot of things in the past. We’ve talked about the fact that we’re under went in the U.S. in insurance, we’ve talked about hidden insurance, we talk about the fact that EMS is an attractive business but we’re a global p
componenttext:
Well, we’ve talked about a lot of things in the past. We’ve talked about the fact that we’re under went in the U.S. in insurance, we’ve talked about hidden insurance, we talk about the fact that EMS is an attractive business but we’re a global player and as a result, we have a lot of products, a lot of geographies and a lot of places that we could improve the franchise. So we consider while there are some obvious things, we consider this on a very broad basis and on a constant basis and we think we can make a difference overtime for the shareholders we will invest.
A good example was mentioned in passing in Dave Duclos’ comments we are building out a unit in North America focused on the construction industry. We’re very excited with the progress of that team. It’s certainly not a time to be expecting big growth in that segment but as we look at where the economy’s headed and some of the bigger, sort of bigger trends, we like being present and ready and we’re willing to invest to be present and ready until the time is, right and that’s the philosophy we’re going to continue to approach this way.

headline: XL Group plc, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much.
componenttext: Thank you very much.

headline: XL Group plc, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hi. Just -- question with respect to capital, I guess. If we look at where you’re sitting today and we contrast it with 2006, property and catastrophe writings are down to a billion three from a billion six in ‘06, the especially writings like aviatio
componenttext: Hi. Just -- question with respect to capital, I guess. If we look at where you’re sitting today and we contrast it with 2006, property and catastrophe writings are down to a billion three from a billion six in ‘06, the especially writings like aviation marine are down to 640 from 750. You’ve got basically stable reserves over that timeframe, asset leverage has come down so I guess as I’m thinking about the amount of capital you need to run your business, are there some areas where capital charges have gone up that might offset the decreases in these areas?

headline: XL Group plc, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I wouldn’t -- first of all, I liked hearing your recitation, sounds like a stronger business and we get that ramp out. I wouldn’t put it in that framework. The emphasis I would put it in is as you know we’ve been getting very positive reviews from t
componenttext:
I wouldn’t -- first of all, I liked hearing your recitation, sounds like a stronger business and we get that ramp out. I wouldn’t put it in that framework. The emphasis I would put it in is as you know we’ve been getting very positive reviews from the rating agencies for our progress in enterprise risk management.
And a big focus of enterprise risk management is establishing the right level of buffer beyond rating agency requirements, beyond regulatory requirements that gives you comfort in how you operate your business such that we can consistently meet our clients’ needs and our shareholders’ expectations.
And I think there’s -- I would -- not that I know with precision the thinking of the past, I would believe based on the performance of the present that we may take a more conservative view of that than may have been viewed in the past and that would probably be a bigger impact than some other capital requirement or emphasis.

headline: XL Group plc, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess what -- I mean, I hear what you’re saying there. What I guess I struggle with in that comment is that I would think that the required buffer given that you would even being conservative today versus ‘06 is likely lower given the CAT reductions
componenttext: I guess what -- I mean, I hear what you’re saying there. What I guess I struggle with in that comment is that I would think that the required buffer given that you would even being conservative today versus ‘06 is likely lower given the CAT reductions, the exit from ICAT, for example, given the asset leverage has come down, since CAT, I think, at least, in the mid, middle of the last decade and the investments more recently seem to have been the back of those?

headline: XL Group plc, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yeah. No. I appreciate that view, and again, I’m not going to -- we’ve never been specific about nor, I’m going to change the policy today on what our capital buffer is but I would just tell you that we’re and the board obviously are pleased with
componenttext: Yeah. No. I appreciate that view, and again, I’m not going to -- we’ve never been specific about nor, I’m going to change the policy today on what our capital buffer is but I would just tell you that we’re and the board obviously are pleased with where we stand today and continue to approach capital management with the exact three-part approach that I mentioned just a moment ago.

headline: XL Group plc, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Fair enough, I won’t belabor it. I guess for one quick for Jamie, is it possible to quantify the amount of business that was impacted by the renewal timing and also what the premium reestimate was just rough order of magnitude?
componenttext: Okay. Fair enough, I won’t belabor it. I guess for one quick for Jamie, is it possible to quantify the amount of business that was impacted by the renewal timing and also what the premium reestimate was just rough order of magnitude?

headline: XL Group plc, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yeah. In the delta and premium was, in the U.S. was principally because of reduced premium from the heartland crop program which was about $22 million. In Bermuda, about $9.4 million was from lower premium on new and renewal business incepting in the quar
componenttext: Yeah. In the delta and premium was, in the U.S. was principally because of reduced premium from the heartland crop program which was about $22 million. In Bermuda, about $9.4 million was from lower premium on new and renewal business incepting in the quarter and the remainder of the $28 million delta was timing issues and so forth.

First, in your casualty business the -- I guess, you said there was -- I guess, an assortment of casualty development that came in worse than expected. I guess, what kind of lines, I guess subcasualty lines were those and also what’s the picture of worker’s comp looking like right now from your perspective?

headline: XL Group plc, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Doug, this is Dave. I guess, couple of things real quick on the casualty question. What we saw in the third quarter a bit of an uptick in terms of loss activity was in our access casualty book. And we don’t get into specifics claimants, but I would say
componenttext:
Doug, this is Dave. I guess, couple of things real quick on the casualty question. What we saw in the third quarter a bit of an uptick in terms of loss activity was in our access casualty book. And we don’t get into specifics claimants, but I would say that the area, in terms of the segment where we’ve seen increase in loss activity is in the energy segment which we’re a player in and we’ve acknowledged in the past.
But again, I want to point out that  on a full year basis it’s not abnormal it’s just in the third quarter we’ve had an increase over what we would consider to be average. And as far as work comp, I’ll say what we’ve been saying in terms of comp writings for the total organization it’s less than 5%, we keep an eye on comp but frankly, we take a very cautious view and growing in comp at this particular point in the market isn’t something we’re looking to do.

headline: XL Group plc, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks for that. My second question is actually about the life business. The -- I know you’ve been winding it down and it can be very lumpy quarter to quarter, I just noticed in the last couple of quarters your life benefits or claims relative to
componenttext: Okay. Thanks for that. My second question is actually about the life business. The -- I know you’ve been winding it down and it can be very lumpy quarter to quarter, I just noticed in the last couple of quarters your life benefits or claims relative to the amount of earned premium flowing through seemed to have been ticking up sequentially. I just wondered, was that just -- is that within the boundaries of the normal noisiness of the quarters or was there any kind of, I guess, longevity or mortality trends that are ticking up or is it industry related or what?

headline: XL Group plc, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: No. We’ve seen nothing on the mortality or other claim side that’s giving rise to any concern in those books. I think, I’m going to -- well, I won’t hazard a guess. Usually, when it gets into movements in that book it winds up being FX but anyway
componenttext: No. We’ve seen nothing on the mortality or other claim side that’s giving rise to any concern in those books. I think, I’m going to -- well, I won’t hazard a guess. Usually, when it gets into movements in that book it winds up being FX but anyway there’s been no claim trends that give us any cause for concern.

headline: XL Group plc, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010

componenttext: Okay. Thanks. And that’s all my questions.

headline: XL Group plc, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I’ll answer the second one first, the reduction in crop was because of the commodity processes that existed in the winter when a lot of that business is bound. On the prior-year releases I will say that, again remaining quite conservative in recen
componenttext: Well, I’ll answer the second one first, the reduction in crop was because of the commodity processes that existed in the winter when a lot of that business is bound. On the prior-year releases I will say that, again remaining quite conservative in recent underwriting years, 95% of the releases were from underwriting years 2007 and prior and of the $87 million that were released only $23 million came from the casualty that’s for short tail lines of business and the $31.7 million that Irene mentioned in her opening remarks which was actually from the 2007 year of account, not the 2000.

componenttext: 2007, okay.

componenttext: And just on the store there, on the crop, we’ve -- that’s a longstanding book, we like that relationship and we like that business. It’s just commodity pricing fluctuations, not appetite fluctuation.

headline: XL Group plc, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ian, this is Dave. And again, we don’t get into naming-specific clients. As I mentioned, it’s -- a couple of them were related to the energy field. We also have an aviation loss. And there’s a bit of randomness to large loss activity. Although, I wo
componenttext:
Ian, this is Dave. And again, we don’t get into naming-specific clients. As I mentioned, it’s -- a couple of them were related to the energy field. We also have an aviation loss. And there’s a bit of randomness to large loss activity. Although, I would point out that XL was not the whole 100% rider on any of these large losses. So it varies in terms of who participates. But it was maybe unfortunately our quarter to have a little bit more then uptick in terms of large loss activity.
Not abnormal as I said if you look at this over a full year basis but that’s about as much color that I’d give you and it’s nothing that causes any concern and the one thing I’d say is we’ve worked awful hard to get this franchise in the spot it is and we’re looking very carefully and underwriting quality. We’re looking at limits, we’re looking at attachment points, we’re looking at the primary risk underwriting and we feel good about that.

headline: XL Group plc, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010

headline: XL Group plc, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just a question on marketing conditions, I assume you saw one of the major brokers put out what I would say is a pretty provocative pressure release essentially advertising that they’re going to get a mid teens price reductions in a numbe
componenttext:
Okay. And then just a question on marketing conditions, I assume you saw one of the major brokers put out what I would say is a pretty provocative pressure release essentially advertising that they’re going to get a mid teens price reductions in a number of lines and basically if you want a reduction, expansion of your terms and conditions ask for it and they’ll get it for you.
What it seemed to -- I understand that’s what the brokers do to some extent but it also seemed like a little bit of a shot across the bow and certainly no mention about, to be prepare for your underwriter to ask for price increases to make up for the -- to get-back in interest rates they’ve had in the last few years. So, I mean do you have a sense that this one on one’s going to be a little bit more combative than pass one ones.

headline: XL Group plc, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the only thing I would absorb is these are very difficult conditions and it’s why we’re so pleased with the discipline we’re seeing in our underwriters. So we -- and I know there’s a lot of them listening tonight and I just want to thank the
componenttext:
Well, the only thing I would absorb is these are very difficult conditions and it’s why we’re so pleased with the discipline we’re seeing in our underwriters. So we -- and I know there’s a lot of them listening tonight and I just want to thank them again because it’s not much fun to be an underwriter right now, but the reality is that kind of market noise is going on around us but it doesn’t influence us. Our job is to write on behalf of our shareholders in what we think is a disciplined way.
And, you know, the only other thing I’d note just based on, what -- what many observe, the last phases of soft markets tend to be the wildest, woolliest and messiest, people started to scrambling disposition for the last bit and whatnot. And so I guess in these difficult days of softer pricing, kind of nothing surprises me. We just work on and keep going.

headline: XL Group plc, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: All right. Just to be honest that was my concern is your exact last comment is do you think that we’re headed towards that, crescendo toward the end this year where I think a lot of people think it’s going to be sort of, stable, slow, steady bleed, do
componenttext: All right. Just to be honest that was my concern is your exact last comment is do you think that we’re headed towards that, crescendo toward the end this year where I think a lot of people think it’s going to be sort of, stable, slow, steady bleed, do you think it will play out as usual?

headline: XL Group plc, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yeah. That’s harder to predict, right? Because you never know when it was truly crazy until you look backwards. But I’ll tell you our view is that -- our job is to just keep -- we’re technically based underwriter, that’s a huge advantage when it c
componenttext:
Yeah. That’s harder to predict, right? Because you never know when it was truly crazy until you look backwards. But I’ll tell you our view is that -- our job is to just keep -- we’re technically based underwriter, that’s a huge advantage when it comes to these kinds of conversations and we just stick to our guns and from it just follow where they may.
But just to go back to Dave’s point on the kind of the higher frequency of, sort of, this severe events, now that’s the business we’re in. Six quarters ago I made the same comment about a quarter that had some of this, again and that’s why we don’t dance when they’re light, we don’t get upset when they’re larger, it’s the nature of XL’s franchise and it’s been a very variable franchise for a reason and the reason is this technical underwriting, we’re not backing off.

headline: XL Group plc, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yeah. I wasn’t really particularly concerned about the large offsets, wanted to understand them better. Just to finish the pricing comments, I mean if there is lines and it sounds like maybe this is a renewal where if there’s longer tail lines where y
componenttext: Yeah. I wasn’t really particularly concerned about the large offsets, wanted to understand them better. Just to finish the pricing comments, I mean if there is lines and it sounds like maybe this is a renewal where if there’s longer tail lines where you think maybe you need to hold the line on price to begin about with and then you need something for, yields maybe you need a 5% increase just to make up for what you’ve lost on NAI, it sounds like it’s should be hard to ask for that, but it basically going to be a renew or walk discussion, not a we need price discussion?

headline: XL Group plc, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I can tell you what. We have without question been disciplined in this. We’ve had a number of instances where we’ve had very difficult discussions with some long time clients and we’ve had to walk and if that’s where the market takes the risk and
componenttext: I can tell you what. We have without question been disciplined in this. We’ve had a number of instances where we’ve had very difficult discussions with some long time clients and we’ve had to walk and if that’s where the market takes the risk and that’s what the buyers are expecting they going to have to get it from somebody else’s capital.

headline: XL Group plc, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sounds good. Pleased to hear it. Thanks, guys.
componenttext: Sounds good. Pleased to hear it. Thanks, guys.

headline: XL Group plc, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Your next question comes from Greg Locraft with Morgan Stanley. You may ask your question.
componenttext: Thank you. Your next question comes from Greg Locraft with Morgan Stanley. You may ask your question.

headline: XL Group plc, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hi. Thanks and good evening. Wanted to just understand on page 30 of the supplement the unrealized loss aging schedule and how it folds in going forward. Are we stuck with realized losses or this unrealized kind of coming through the income statement for
componenttext: Hi. Thanks and good evening. Wanted to just understand on page 30 of the supplement the unrealized loss aging schedule and how it folds in going forward. Are we stuck with realized losses or this unrealized kind of coming through the income statement for the foreseeable future?

headline: XL Group plc, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think it all depends on what happens in the quality of the assets. I mean, the realized losses at this point principally in non-agency RMBS and in our CDO portfolio and it’s really going to come down to each quarter we sit down and we review those, up
componenttext: I think it all depends on what happens in the quality of the assets. I mean, the realized losses at this point principally in non-agency RMBS and in our CDO portfolio and it’s really going to come down to each quarter we sit down and we review those, updating our assumptions and if we see deterioration, we take the pain. But, I mean, we’ll point out for the first time in a long time we’re actually now in a net gain position on the overall portfolio which shows the amount of improvement we have had in terms of recovering in those assets.

headline: XL Group plc, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess what I’m wondering is, it looks like most of these assets have now been sitting in an unrealized loss position for more than 12 months. And we’ve just come off of a one heck of a rally year-to-date in the fixed income markets. And so I’m jus
componenttext: I guess what I’m wondering is, it looks like most of these assets have now been sitting in an unrealized loss position for more than 12 months. And we’ve just come off of a one heck of a rally year-to-date in the fixed income markets. And so I’m just wondering why this doesn’t come through the income statement quicker. Are you guys marking to model in effect and just choosing to hold or how do we think about this and then how does it tie to your operating ROE goals or is it totally excluded from the operating ROE goals?

headline: XL Group plc, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, one, it is excluded from the operating ROE goal because it’s a net income number. I will say there’s no hard time test that says once the security has been impaired with a certain period of time we have to write it down. It all comes down to the
componenttext: Well, one, it is excluded from the operating ROE goal because it’s a net income number. I will say there’s no hard time test that says once the security has been impaired with a certain period of time we have to write it down. It all comes down to the underlying credit quality and whether we think that’s going to recover and we do every quarter, we’ve continued to see recovery in a number of these legacy assets. Including this latest quarter and they are all marked to market using third-party sources so nothing is priced internally at this point.

headline: XL Group plc, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. Thank you for your help.
componenttext: Okay. Great. Thank you for your help.

If it’s a buyback activity level that you conducted in the month of October is a reasonable activity level going forward on a monthly basis. Thanks. And best of luck, hope it continues.

headline: XL Group plc, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Rob, thank you very much. And that’s a completely understandable question, I’m afraid I have to give the same answer I’ve given before. We’re going to keep reviewing what’s going on in the market, we’re going to keep reviewing what our positio
componenttext:
Rob, thank you very much. And that’s a completely understandable question, I’m afraid I have to give the same answer I’ve given before. We’re going to keep reviewing what’s going on in the market, we’re going to keep reviewing what our position is relative to our writings, relative to our view of our capital buffers, relative in opportunities to put it to work and then whether -- at what level to return it to shareholders.
That will be a constant evaluation so we’re simply not in a position to give a forecast of what the answer to those changing factors will be in the future. But I appreciate the question and it’s -- somehow it’s a nicer question to have, than the question I was getting for the last few quarters which is always when the heck are you going to do something. At least it’s -- at least we’ve shown that there are tradition which we will and have. Yeah. I appreciate that.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would like to welcome everyone to the XL Capital Ltd. first quarter earnings call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to David Radulski, XL’s Director of Investor Relations.
componenttext: I would like to welcome everyone to the XL Capital Ltd. first quarter earnings call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to David Radulski, XL’s Director of Investor Relations.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good evening, and welcome to XL Capital’s first quarter 2010 earnings conference call. This call is being simultaneously webcast on XL’s website at www.xlcapital.com. We’ve posted to our website several documents including our quarterly financial su
componenttext:
Good evening, and welcome to XL Capital’s first quarter 2010 earnings conference call. This call is being simultaneously webcast on XL’s website at www.xlcapital.com. We’ve posted to our website several documents including our quarterly financial supplement and our fixed income portfolio data.
On our call today, Mike McGavick, XL Capital’s CEO will offer opening remarks. Simon Rich, our Interim CFO will review our financial results followed by David Duclos, our Chief Executive of Insurance Operations and Jamie Veghte, Chief Executive of ReInsurance operations who will review the segment results and market conditions. Sarah Street, our Chief Investment Officer is with us today and available for Q&A.
Before we begin, I’d like to remind you that certain of the matters we’ll discuss today are forward-looking statements. These statements are based on current plans, estimates and expectations. Forward-looking statements involve inherent risks and uncertainties and a number of factors could cause actual results to differ materially from those contained in the forward-looking statements, and therefore you should not place undue reliance on them.
Forward-looking statements are sensitive to many factors including those identified in our annual report on Form 10-K, our quarterly reports on Form 10-Q and other documents on file with the SEC that could cause actual results to differ materially from those contained in the forward-looking statements.
Forward-looking statements speak only as of the date on which they are made and we undertake no obligation publicly to revise any forward-looking statement in response to new information, future developments or otherwise.
And with that, I’ll turn it over to Mike McGavick.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good evening. I’m pleased to report to you another quarter of solid operating results even as the global P&C industry experienced some of its worst quarter one-cat events ever. Our nearly breakeven P&C combined ratio of 100.5 included a 14.3 points from
componenttext:
Good evening. I’m pleased to report to you another quarter of solid operating results even as the global P&C industry experienced some of its worst quarter one-cat events ever. Our nearly breakeven P&C combined ratio of 100.5 included a 14.3 points from the Chilean earthquake and storm Xynthia as our estimates from these losses from these two events remains within the preliminary range we published in March.
We did see some offsets against these caps with 6.9 point of positive prior year development, mostly from short sale property lines in both Insurance and ReInsurance. For the fourth consecutive quarter, we grew out book value for ordinary share, this time another 7% to $26.38 and by 8% intangible book value per share to $23.92, and total shareholders’ equity increased from $9.4 billion to $10 billion.
The first quarter caps impact on operating income and the continued increase in our shareholders' equity resulted in annualized operating ROE of 6.9% for the first quarter. Without the impact of the two named cats, our operating ROE would have been 14.2%.
We see these results as an endorsement of our continued discipline in both underwriting and risk management, and I’ve said before, and I’ll say it again, perhaps as much for the benefit of any XL underwriters who are listening in, XL will not write coverage at uneconomic price levels.
So while we grew our P&C top line by 2.3% year over year, much of that growth, as we had anticipated and predicted at the beginning of the year, came from lines we found attractive, including aerospace, cat and DNO as well as several long time customers returning to XL. We welcomed them back.
Meanwhile, we continue to lower our premiums written for multi-year Insurance premiums and from uneconomic businesses such as casualty, factory and Insurance that we exited last year.
It was a quiet quarter for our investment portfolio, which is looking more like the P&C portfolio should, as our optimization program continues. And while we saw the benefit of a $522 million in favorable marks to market this quarter, I should remind you that what goes up goes down and as interest rates can rise or fall, we’ll just have to see what happens next.
We do know that our excellent liquidity and well-matched asset liability profile will let us ride out any interest rate volatility.
On a risk management note, in March of 2009, we instructed our portfolio managers, and here I guess I’m more in line with current news, I instructed our managers back in March of 2009 to stop purchasing sovereign debt from Greece and Ireland and severely restricted exposures to the debt of Portugal, Italy and Spain.
So our cumulative exposure to sovereign debt from these five countries is down to approximately $34 million or less than 1/10 of 1% of our entire investment portfolio, including no exposure to Greece.
Likewise, we made significant progress on another risk management initiative. Last week, as you well know, our ordinary shareholders approved several proposals, most notably our change of parent domicile from the Cayman Islands to Ireland.
There are several more conditions to satisfy before this move will be complete, but shareholder approval was a significant move in the right direction, and we thank our shareholders for supporting the recommendations of management and the Board.
Also in current news, as you noticed in our release yesterday, we are very pleased to announce that Irene Esteves has agreed to join XL as our Chief Financial Officer. She is a deeply experienced business leader and we’re delighted to have her on our team. Irene joins us on May 17.
You can also look forward to the release of our global loss triangles this week. Now I’ll finish my remarks on the first quarter by saying that XL is once again firing on all cylinders in a very difficult market condition.
Our underlying P&C results are solid and showing positive trends. Our risk management efforts are proving out and our organization, we believe, is getting stronger by the day. While the entire P&C faces challenges deploying capital in this kind of pricing environment, we believe we can build on XL’s success by providing our brokers and customers with the coverages they value and the service they demand.
Before I turn it over to Simon, I should comment on the terrible events in the Gulf of Mexico. Like anyone on this call, we deeply mourn the loss of life and we’re all watching with horror the continuing and likely environmental damage.
It’s much too early to know what the insurable losses are on a total basis, and what portion of these losses XL might cover, but we can say this. We believe that our total property damage exposure to the rig itself is approximately $30 million including $5 million in reinstatement premiums and we have in fact, already paid much of this in claims. For what it’s worth, that would equate to a roughly $900 million industry event.
Now as I hand it over to Simon, I would like to thank him publicly for his outstanding service as XL’s interim CFO since the first of the year. Thanks, Simon, and on to you.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike, and good evening. Before I comment on the results of the quarter, I wanted to take a moment to expand on the comment in our press release on our calculation of operating income.We manage foreign exchange volatility from an economic perspec
componenttext:
Thanks, Mike, and good evening. Before I comment on the results of the quarter, I wanted to take a moment to expand on the comment in our press release on our calculation of operating income.
We manage foreign exchange volatility from an economic perspective through the matching of assets and liabilities. However, GAAP provides an asymmetrical treatment for the movement of assets and liabilities with the results of a foreign exchange gain or loss in the income statement really doesn’t represent any underlying economics.
We’ve discussed this with a number of you and what you’ve told us is that you too, really don’t find it a relevant indicator of performance. Accordingly, we’ve decided that we will no longer include foreign exchange gains and losses within our operating income, and we’ve represented prior periods on a consistent basis.
Page 30 of our financial supplements shows the operating income for each of the quarters since the first quarter of 2009 on this new basis. And now to the results themselves.
Operating income for the quarter was $150 million or $0.44 per ordinary share with an annualized operation ROE of 6.9%. This compares to $191 million, $0.57 per ordinary share and 14.9% respectively in the prior year quarter.
Turning to our summary financial results on Slide 4, P&C gross premiums written were up by 2.3% from the prior year quarter, reflecting targeted new business growth including the recapture of certain business lost in 2009, and $15 million more of noncatastrophe related reinstatement premiums than in the prior year quarter.
P&C net premiums written increased by 6.1% reflecting a reduction in the levels of seeded premium in the quarter. I would say that part of this is a timing difference and we expect some $25 million of ReInsurance purchases that would otherwise have been made in the first quarter to occur in later quarters this year.
P&C net premiums were down 4.4% in the first quarter compared to the first quarter of 2009. This reflects the rolling effects of prior period’s lower written premium. The P&C combined ratio for the first quarter of 100.5% shows the effect of first quarter cats of $181 million, which as set out on Slide 5, added 14.3 points to the loss ratio for the quarter.
This was offset in part by favorable prior year development of $87 million, which is line with the $90 million recognized in the prior year quarter. In the current quarter, $72 million of the releases were from short tail lines.
Our underlying combined ratio excluding prior year development and natural catastrophe was 93.1%, 3.8 points better than the prior year quarter. This improvement reflects the restructuring costs in the first quarter of 2009, changes in our business mix and the benefits of the higher non-catastrophe reinstatement premiums I referred to earlier.
Investment income on the P&C portfolio decreased in Q1 compared to the prior year quarter. This was due to lower portfolio yield, driven by the decline in LIBOR, combined with high concentrations of cash and governments as we move towards a portfolio that’s more typical of a P&C insurer.
During the quarter, we put new money to work largely in investment-grade credit, achieving an average rate of 3.2% and as a result, P&C’s duration increased marginally to three years. At March 31, 2010, the P&C portfolio book yield gross of fees, was 3.6%.
As a result of recent developments in certain European government markets, we’ve added additional disclosures to our fixed income supplement. As you can see, within the Eurozone, 94% of our government holdings are in France and Germany.
At $229 million of operating expenses for the quarter, with $39 million or 15% lower year over year. The reduction arises principally from the fact that we incurred some $40 million of restructuring costs in the prior year quarter, with this reduction offset in part by $6 million of higher reported expenses arising from foreign exchange rate fluctuations.
In the first quarter, we recognized a gain to ordinary shareholders of $16.6 million from the further repurchase of Series C preference shares and now the remaining par value outstanding of those shares is only $71.9 million.
The main drivers of our 7% growth in book value per ordinary share were operating earnings and the favorable mark to market of $522 million during the quarter. This arose from tightening credit spreads and from lower interest rates, and as set out on Slide 3, we ended the first quarter with over $12.5 billion in total capital, an increase of over 4% in the quarter.
Now over to David.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Insurance segment results for the first quarter were strong considering the impact of Q1 cats including most notably the Chilean earthquake. Our combined ratio of 101.6% for the quarter was 2.7 points higher than our Q1 2009 results of 98.9%, which had be
componenttext:
Insurance segment results for the first quarter were strong considering the impact of Q1 cats including most notably the Chilean earthquake. Our combined ratio of 101.6% for the quarter was 2.7 points higher than our Q1 2009 results of 98.9%, which had been favorably impacted by limited cat activity. Adjusting for both cat and prior year development, the Insurance segment’s 2010 combined ratio of 96.4% was 2.7 points better than the same period last year.
Gross premiums written in Q1 increased 3.7% or $41 million year over year. We are fully aware of the difficult trading environment, and I can assure you that we are in no way relaxing our underwriting discipline. Our growth was led by selected business wins and increased participation in attractive lines including professional, marine, upper middle market and aviation.
As Mike mentioned, it also included some significant win backs in several lines including professional, which is particularly rewarding. Net premiums earned were down just over 1% or $13 million as we recognized the anticipated earn through of last year’s lower gross premiums written.
On the loss side, Q1 cat losses were partially offset by some favorable prior year development largely in our short tail lines. Our Q1 2010 loss ratio was 72.3% compares to 67.6% last year. However, when adjusted for both cats and prior year development, our underlying loss rate ratio is slightly better year over year at 67.1% versus 67.85. This was driven primarily by a lack of property losses, exiting less attractive businesses and the related shift in business mix.
Acquisition expenses were up slightly, reflecting modestly higher brokerage commissions in some line as well as a change in our business mix to lines such as professional and specialty that have always had higher brokerage commission structures.
This was partially offset by reduced operating expenses as our previously announced expense and organizational initiatives took hold. Total expense ratio for Q1 2010 of 29.3% was two points lower than Q1 2009.
Before I move on to market conditions, let me provide a couple of comments on our Professional book and why our profitability outlook remains in line with expectations. First, we saw lower than expected claims activity during the first quarter in our core professional book as the overall industry SEC class action frequency was lower than for the same period of 2009.
Second, various financial crisis-related matters from the 2007 and 2008 period developed favorably for XL along with the rest of the DNO industry during the quarter. As a result, we remain comfortable with our initial valuation of XL’s financial crisis exposure and the reserves we hold against it.
Regarding the market, despite the challenging macro economic conditions faced by many of our clients we continue to see clear and steady improvements in both retentions and new business submissions throughout our book. Our premium retentions for the first quarter were just over 85% on a segment basis, significantly better than the low 70’s experienced in Q1 2009. We are now back on track for historical retention levels.
What does give us concern is broad market pricing. After 3 quarters of modest increases of plus 1% and plus 2%, we saw some give back as our overall pricing declined 1% for the first quarter, slightly better than the Q1 2009 decline of 1.6%. We saw this reflected across most lines, with the only notable pricing increases recorded in our specialty book.
While we recognize the challenging market, we continue to build on our Insurance foundations of underwriting and claims bank. We successfully recruited two market leaders, [ Zarana Mogg ] and Patrick Tannic to join our team. Zarana will be joining us as Chief Executive of our North America P&C unit and Patrick is already on board as our Bermuda country manager. Welcome.
Operationally we turned the switch on our new centralized global claims management system in the U.S., Canada and Bermuda. We see improved customer service, faster response, and lower cost as only three of the benefits of this upgrade. We intend to expand the system throughout South American, Europe and Asia next year.
XL is approaching 2010 much as we finished 2009. We continue to renew existing books of business where rates are acceptable. We’re selectively writing new business at the right price, and we continue taking necessary actions to lower our expenses, all while remaining disciplined in our underwriting and engage with our brokers and clients.
I’ll finish with some observations we made at RIMS, which was held in Boston last week. XL hosted over 225 client meetings at RIMS and we heard time and again what they were looking for; a lead writer than can provide existing and new products and services supported by solid risk engineering, a clear history of claims performance and a global presence, all supported by a solid capital foundation. It was reassuring to hear that, what they want, we can provide.
And now to Jamie to discuss ReInsurance.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, David, and good evening. XL RE also enjoyed a positive quarter in difficult market conditions and significant levels of natural catastrophe activity. Our underwriting results for the quarter were good with a combined ratio of 97.8% resulting in an
componenttext:
Thanks, David, and good evening. XL RE also enjoyed a positive quarter in difficult market conditions and significant levels of natural catastrophe activity. Our underwriting results for the quarter were good with a combined ratio of 97.8% resulting in an underwriting profit of $8.1 million. This compares with a combined ratio of 77.2% in Q1 of 2009.
Embedded in these results were losses of $81.6 million and $19.9 million from the Chilean earthquake and windstorm Xynthia respectively. The result also included positive prior year reserve releases of $53.8 million.
Adjusting for cat losses and prior year releases, the segment had a combined ratio of 84.8%, a 7 point improvement over the first quarter of 2009. This improvement was driven by 3.5 points on the expense ratio related to our U.S. crop portfolio, acquisition, the cost of adjustments in Bermuda and Europe and non-recurring severance charges from the first quarter of 2009.
The loss ratio also had a 3.5 point improvement driven by the benefit of reinstatement premiums in Europe on nonproperty business and a mix of business impact on property increase proportionately and a decrease in our trade credit business.
Turning to top line gross net premiums written were $790 million and $695 million respectively, basically flat year over year growth and a 3% increase net driven by reduced sessions on our multi-carrier crop portfolio.
Finally, turning tour Life Operations, contribution during the quarter was $49 million. This included a one-time gain of $13.8 million as a result of three treaties being commuted with clients.
I’d like to comment briefly on the Chilean earthquake before turning to market conditions. While it’s still early, and we are relying heavily on model results to establish our net loss estimate, we feel very good about our performance in this event. Our Latin American business unit contributed $66 million of the $82 million total loss to the segment with the remainder emanating from Bermuda and our London retro book.
Based on our estimate market share as published by the Superintendant of Insurance in Chile and assuming an industry loss of $6 billion to $8 billion, which we believe to be the case, our net loss is well below what peer market share analysis would indicate. This is principally due to fairly aggressive use of what I would describe as spot retrocession purchasing in the region.
The distribution of this loss into the industry with perhaps upwards of 80% to 90% into the ReInsurance market, is reflective of some broader issues in emerging markets we believe need to be addressed by the industry. This would include heavy reliance on proportional Insurance, event or assess the limits on these structures at levels that make them virtually meaningless, inadequate underlying rate levels and commission structures that do not allow sufficient margin to fund events of this magnitude.
While the event will obviously provide the market with an opportunity to address underlying rate adequacy, we will also advocate significant structural change in the market, principally a reliance on nonproportional ReInsurance, our preferred product.
As we’ve mentioned in our last few calls, market conditions remain challenging. We’ve kept our top line flat due principally to recaptured business that was lost at year-end 2008 and selected new opportunities, mostly in Europe.
We are broadly concerned about market conditions however. For example, our Japanese cap portfolio just turned over April 1, with a risk adjusted reduction in pricing of 5.5%. This is in a market that clearly needed more rate as we entered the renewal, and as a result, we reduced our position in this very important market yet again.
On the long tail side as David mentioned, there is broad competition across the market although we do see pockets of positive in some areas of the professional lines and U.K. for example. Overall, we’re very pleased with our underwriting performance against this backdrop and we will continue to be vigilant with our underwriting as this phase of the market plays itself out.
With that, I will turn it back to David for Q&A.

componenttext: Regarding what may happen with the stock and the indexes. Would XL be willing to repurchase its own shares if the stock were cheap enough under technical price threats?

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don’t think it would do us any good to comment on any specific will or won’t. I would refer you simply to our general guidance about capital management. We believe the first job is to make sure we have enough capital to weather any storm according t
componenttext:
I don’t think it would do us any good to comment on any specific will or won’t. I would refer you simply to our general guidance about capital management. We believe the first job is to make sure we have enough capital to weather any storm according to our standards, not just the rating agencies and the regulators.
We would second of course, look for where else in our sector we could put it to work for good advantage for our shareholders, and then third, if we had enough by the first test and by the second test, and had nowhere advantageous to put it, then we would look at returning it to our shareholders by whatever we thought was the best method and obviously in doing so, we would always want to do so in a wise way and being opportunistic would be one of the wise ways to do so.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Have you had any discussions with the rating agencies about capital assets monitoring? You monitor your own capital, but the rating agencies do have the badge and the gun to some extent.
componenttext: Have you had any discussions with the rating agencies about capital assets monitoring? You monitor your own capital, but the rating agencies do have the badge and the gun to some extent.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: There’s no doubt about that. It’s a big gun. We are in constant contact with our rating agencies. I always have to let them speak for themselves. It’s inappropriate for me to do so. I can only tell you that from our end, we consider those conversati
componenttext: There’s no doubt about that. It’s a big gun. We are in constant contact with our rating agencies. I always have to let them speak for themselves. It’s inappropriate for me to do so. I can only tell you that from our end, we consider those conversations to be very constructive. Obviously, they can see these results just as you can. We think all the markers of the strengthening and healthy franchise are present.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: There is noise in the year over year top line numbers and we would suggest that when you normalize for all of those various elements, the noise whether FX or programs that we’re exiting that are running off versus growth in lines that we’re very posit
componenttext:
There is noise in the year over year top line numbers and we would suggest that when you normalize for all of those various elements, the noise whether FX or programs that we’re exiting that are running off versus growth in lines that we’re very positive about, I would put it really in Insurance kind of near the 10% range would be the actual kind of preferred book on preferred book growth.
So we’re very pleased with that number. We examine ourselves very closely given the market conditions and remain pleased. On ReInsurance, it’s flattish over time, maybe even slightly negative.
But in terms of pricing, I’ll let my colleagues who are even closer to the markets talk about that.
