headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good evening, and welcome to XL Capital’s first quarter 2010 earnings conference call. This call is being simultaneously webcast on XL’s website at www.xlcapital.com. We’ve posted to our website several documents including our quarterly financial su
componenttext:
Good evening, and welcome to XL Capital’s first quarter 2010 earnings conference call. This call is being simultaneously webcast on XL’s website at www.xlcapital.com. We’ve posted to our website several documents including our quarterly financial supplement and our fixed income portfolio data.
On our call today, Mike McGavick, XL Capital’s CEO will offer opening remarks. Simon Rich, our Interim CFO will review our financial results followed by David Duclos, our Chief Executive of Insurance Operations and Jamie Veghte, Chief Executive of ReInsurance operations who will review the segment results and market conditions. Sarah Street, our Chief Investment Officer is with us today and available for Q&A.
Before we begin, I’d like to remind you that certain of the matters we’ll discuss today are forward-looking statements. These statements are based on current plans, estimates and expectations. Forward-looking statements involve inherent risks and uncertainties and a number of factors could cause actual results to differ materially from those contained in the forward-looking statements, and therefore you should not place undue reliance on them.
Forward-looking statements are sensitive to many factors including those identified in our annual report on Form 10-K, our quarterly reports on Form 10-Q and other documents on file with the SEC that could cause actual results to differ materially from those contained in the forward-looking statements.
Forward-looking statements speak only as of the date on which they are made and we undertake no obligation publicly to revise any forward-looking statement in response to new information, future developments or otherwise.
And with that, I’ll turn it over to Mike McGavick.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good evening. I’m pleased to report to you another quarter of solid operating results even as the global P&C industry experienced some of its worst quarter one-cat events ever. Our nearly breakeven P&C combined ratio of 100.5 included a 14.3 points from
componenttext:
Good evening. I’m pleased to report to you another quarter of solid operating results even as the global P&C industry experienced some of its worst quarter one-cat events ever. Our nearly breakeven P&C combined ratio of 100.5 included a 14.3 points from the Chilean earthquake and storm Xynthia as our estimates from these losses from these two events remains within the preliminary range we published in March.
We did see some offsets against these caps with 6.9 point of positive prior year development, mostly from short sale property lines in both Insurance and ReInsurance. For the fourth consecutive quarter, we grew out book value for ordinary share, this time another 7% to $26.38 and by 8% intangible book value per share to $23.92, and total shareholders’ equity increased from $9.4 billion to $10 billion.
The first quarter caps impact on operating income and the continued increase in our shareholders' equity resulted in annualized operating ROE of 6.9% for the first quarter. Without the impact of the two named cats, our operating ROE would have been 14.2%.
We see these results as an endorsement of our continued discipline in both underwriting and risk management, and I’ve said before, and I’ll say it again, perhaps as much for the benefit of any XL underwriters who are listening in, XL will not write coverage at uneconomic price levels.
So while we grew our P&C top line by 2.3% year over year, much of that growth, as we had anticipated and predicted at the beginning of the year, came from lines we found attractive, including aerospace, cat and DNO as well as several long time customers returning to XL. We welcomed them back.
Meanwhile, we continue to lower our premiums written for multi-year Insurance premiums and from uneconomic businesses such as casualty, factory and Insurance that we exited last year.
It was a quiet quarter for our investment portfolio, which is looking more like the P&C portfolio should, as our optimization program continues. And while we saw the benefit of a $522 million in favorable marks to market this quarter, I should remind you that what goes up goes down and as interest rates can rise or fall, we’ll just have to see what happens next.
We do know that our excellent liquidity and well-matched asset liability profile will let us ride out any interest rate volatility.
On a risk management note, in March of 2009, we instructed our portfolio managers, and here I guess I’m more in line with current news, I instructed our managers back in March of 2009 to stop purchasing sovereign debt from Greece and Ireland and severely restricted exposures to the debt of Portugal, Italy and Spain.
So our cumulative exposure to sovereign debt from these five countries is down to approximately $34 million or less than 1/10 of 1% of our entire investment portfolio, including no exposure to Greece.
Likewise, we made significant progress on another risk management initiative. Last week, as you well know, our ordinary shareholders approved several proposals, most notably our change of parent domicile from the Cayman Islands to Ireland.
There are several more conditions to satisfy before this move will be complete, but shareholder approval was a significant move in the right direction, and we thank our shareholders for supporting the recommendations of management and the Board.
Also in current news, as you noticed in our release yesterday, we are very pleased to announce that Irene Esteves has agreed to join XL as our Chief Financial Officer. She is a deeply experienced business leader and we’re delighted to have her on our team. Irene joins us on May 17.
You can also look forward to the release of our global loss triangles this week. Now I’ll finish my remarks on the first quarter by saying that XL is once again firing on all cylinders in a very difficult market condition.
Our underlying P&C results are solid and showing positive trends. Our risk management efforts are proving out and our organization, we believe, is getting stronger by the day. While the entire P&C faces challenges deploying capital in this kind of pricing environment, we believe we can build on XL’s success by providing our brokers and customers with the coverages they value and the service they demand.
Before I turn it over to Simon, I should comment on the terrible events in the Gulf of Mexico. Like anyone on this call, we deeply mourn the loss of life and we’re all watching with horror the continuing and likely environmental damage.
It’s much too early to know what the insurable losses are on a total basis, and what portion of these losses XL might cover, but we can say this. We believe that our total property damage exposure to the rig itself is approximately $30 million including $5 million in reinstatement premiums and we have in fact, already paid much of this in claims. For what it’s worth, that would equate to a roughly $900 million industry event.
Now as I hand it over to Simon, I would like to thank him publicly for his outstanding service as XL’s interim CFO since the first of the year. Thanks, Simon, and on to you.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike, and good evening. Before I comment on the results of the quarter, I wanted to take a moment to expand on the comment in our press release on our calculation of operating income.We manage foreign exchange volatility from an economic perspec
componenttext:
Thanks, Mike, and good evening. Before I comment on the results of the quarter, I wanted to take a moment to expand on the comment in our press release on our calculation of operating income.
We manage foreign exchange volatility from an economic perspective through the matching of assets and liabilities. However, GAAP provides an asymmetrical treatment for the movement of assets and liabilities with the results of a foreign exchange gain or loss in the income statement really doesn’t represent any underlying economics.
We’ve discussed this with a number of you and what you’ve told us is that you too, really don’t find it a relevant indicator of performance. Accordingly, we’ve decided that we will no longer include foreign exchange gains and losses within our operating income, and we’ve represented prior periods on a consistent basis.
Page 30 of our financial supplements shows the operating income for each of the quarters since the first quarter of 2009 on this new basis. And now to the results themselves.
Operating income for the quarter was $150 million or $0.44 per ordinary share with an annualized operation ROE of 6.9%. This compares to $191 million, $0.57 per ordinary share and 14.9% respectively in the prior year quarter.
Turning to our summary financial results on Slide 4, P&C gross premiums written were up by 2.3% from the prior year quarter, reflecting targeted new business growth including the recapture of certain business lost in 2009, and $15 million more of noncatastrophe related reinstatement premiums than in the prior year quarter.
P&C net premiums written increased by 6.1% reflecting a reduction in the levels of seeded premium in the quarter. I would say that part of this is a timing difference and we expect some $25 million of ReInsurance purchases that would otherwise have been made in the first quarter to occur in later quarters this year.
P&C net premiums were down 4.4% in the first quarter compared to the first quarter of 2009. This reflects the rolling effects of prior period’s lower written premium. The P&C combined ratio for the first quarter of 100.5% shows the effect of first quarter cats of $181 million, which as set out on Slide 5, added 14.3 points to the loss ratio for the quarter.
This was offset in part by favorable prior year development of $87 million, which is line with the $90 million recognized in the prior year quarter. In the current quarter, $72 million of the releases were from short tail lines.
Our underlying combined ratio excluding prior year development and natural catastrophe was 93.1%, 3.8 points better than the prior year quarter. This improvement reflects the restructuring costs in the first quarter of 2009, changes in our business mix and the benefits of the higher non-catastrophe reinstatement premiums I referred to earlier.
Investment income on the P&C portfolio decreased in Q1 compared to the prior year quarter. This was due to lower portfolio yield, driven by the decline in LIBOR, combined with high concentrations of cash and governments as we move towards a portfolio that’s more typical of a P&C insurer.
During the quarter, we put new money to work largely in investment-grade credit, achieving an average rate of 3.2% and as a result, P&C’s duration increased marginally to three years. At March 31, 2010, the P&C portfolio book yield gross of fees, was 3.6%.
As a result of recent developments in certain European government markets, we’ve added additional disclosures to our fixed income supplement. As you can see, within the Eurozone, 94% of our government holdings are in France and Germany.
At $229 million of operating expenses for the quarter, with $39 million or 15% lower year over year. The reduction arises principally from the fact that we incurred some $40 million of restructuring costs in the prior year quarter, with this reduction offset in part by $6 million of higher reported expenses arising from foreign exchange rate fluctuations.
In the first quarter, we recognized a gain to ordinary shareholders of $16.6 million from the further repurchase of Series C preference shares and now the remaining par value outstanding of those shares is only $71.9 million.
The main drivers of our 7% growth in book value per ordinary share were operating earnings and the favorable mark to market of $522 million during the quarter. This arose from tightening credit spreads and from lower interest rates, and as set out on Slide 3, we ended the first quarter with over $12.5 billion in total capital, an increase of over 4% in the quarter.
Now over to David.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Insurance segment results for the first quarter were strong considering the impact of Q1 cats including most notably the Chilean earthquake. Our combined ratio of 101.6% for the quarter was 2.7 points higher than our Q1 2009 results of 98.9%, which had be
componenttext:
Insurance segment results for the first quarter were strong considering the impact of Q1 cats including most notably the Chilean earthquake. Our combined ratio of 101.6% for the quarter was 2.7 points higher than our Q1 2009 results of 98.9%, which had been favorably impacted by limited cat activity. Adjusting for both cat and prior year development, the Insurance segment’s 2010 combined ratio of 96.4% was 2.7 points better than the same period last year.
Gross premiums written in Q1 increased 3.7% or $41 million year over year. We are fully aware of the difficult trading environment, and I can assure you that we are in no way relaxing our underwriting discipline. Our growth was led by selected business wins and increased participation in attractive lines including professional, marine, upper middle market and aviation.
As Mike mentioned, it also included some significant win backs in several lines including professional, which is particularly rewarding. Net premiums earned were down just over 1% or $13 million as we recognized the anticipated earn through of last year’s lower gross premiums written.
On the loss side, Q1 cat losses were partially offset by some favorable prior year development largely in our short tail lines. Our Q1 2010 loss ratio was 72.3% compares to 67.6% last year. However, when adjusted for both cats and prior year development, our underlying loss rate ratio is slightly better year over year at 67.1% versus 67.85. This was driven primarily by a lack of property losses, exiting less attractive businesses and the related shift in business mix.
Acquisition expenses were up slightly, reflecting modestly higher brokerage commissions in some line as well as a change in our business mix to lines such as professional and specialty that have always had higher brokerage commission structures.
This was partially offset by reduced operating expenses as our previously announced expense and organizational initiatives took hold. Total expense ratio for Q1 2010 of 29.3% was two points lower than Q1 2009.
Before I move on to market conditions, let me provide a couple of comments on our Professional book and why our profitability outlook remains in line with expectations. First, we saw lower than expected claims activity during the first quarter in our core professional book as the overall industry SEC class action frequency was lower than for the same period of 2009.
Second, various financial crisis-related matters from the 2007 and 2008 period developed favorably for XL along with the rest of the DNO industry during the quarter. As a result, we remain comfortable with our initial valuation of XL’s financial crisis exposure and the reserves we hold against it.
Regarding the market, despite the challenging macro economic conditions faced by many of our clients we continue to see clear and steady improvements in both retentions and new business submissions throughout our book. Our premium retentions for the first quarter were just over 85% on a segment basis, significantly better than the low 70’s experienced in Q1 2009. We are now back on track for historical retention levels.
What does give us concern is broad market pricing. After 3 quarters of modest increases of plus 1% and plus 2%, we saw some give back as our overall pricing declined 1% for the first quarter, slightly better than the Q1 2009 decline of 1.6%. We saw this reflected across most lines, with the only notable pricing increases recorded in our specialty book.
While we recognize the challenging market, we continue to build on our Insurance foundations of underwriting and claims bank. We successfully recruited two market leaders, [ Zarana Mogg ] and Patrick Tannic to join our team. Zarana will be joining us as Chief Executive of our North America P&C unit and Patrick is already on board as our Bermuda country manager. Welcome.
Operationally we turned the switch on our new centralized global claims management system in the U.S., Canada and Bermuda. We see improved customer service, faster response, and lower cost as only three of the benefits of this upgrade. We intend to expand the system throughout South American, Europe and Asia next year.
XL is approaching 2010 much as we finished 2009. We continue to renew existing books of business where rates are acceptable. We’re selectively writing new business at the right price, and we continue taking necessary actions to lower our expenses, all while remaining disciplined in our underwriting and engage with our brokers and clients.
I’ll finish with some observations we made at RIMS, which was held in Boston last week. XL hosted over 225 client meetings at RIMS and we heard time and again what they were looking for; a lead writer than can provide existing and new products and services supported by solid risk engineering, a clear history of claims performance and a global presence, all supported by a solid capital foundation. It was reassuring to hear that, what they want, we can provide.
And now to Jamie to discuss ReInsurance.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, David, and good evening. XL RE also enjoyed a positive quarter in difficult market conditions and significant levels of natural catastrophe activity. Our underwriting results for the quarter were good with a combined ratio of 97.8% resulting in an
componenttext:
Thanks, David, and good evening. XL RE also enjoyed a positive quarter in difficult market conditions and significant levels of natural catastrophe activity. Our underwriting results for the quarter were good with a combined ratio of 97.8% resulting in an underwriting profit of $8.1 million. This compares with a combined ratio of 77.2% in Q1 of 2009.
Embedded in these results were losses of $81.6 million and $19.9 million from the Chilean earthquake and windstorm Xynthia respectively. The result also included positive prior year reserve releases of $53.8 million.
Adjusting for cat losses and prior year releases, the segment had a combined ratio of 84.8%, a 7 point improvement over the first quarter of 2009. This improvement was driven by 3.5 points on the expense ratio related to our U.S. crop portfolio, acquisition, the cost of adjustments in Bermuda and Europe and non-recurring severance charges from the first quarter of 2009.
The loss ratio also had a 3.5 point improvement driven by the benefit of reinstatement premiums in Europe on nonproperty business and a mix of business impact on property increase proportionately and a decrease in our trade credit business.
Turning to top line gross net premiums written were $790 million and $695 million respectively, basically flat year over year growth and a 3% increase net driven by reduced sessions on our multi-carrier crop portfolio.
Finally, turning tour Life Operations, contribution during the quarter was $49 million. This included a one-time gain of $13.8 million as a result of three treaties being commuted with clients.
I’d like to comment briefly on the Chilean earthquake before turning to market conditions. While it’s still early, and we are relying heavily on model results to establish our net loss estimate, we feel very good about our performance in this event. Our Latin American business unit contributed $66 million of the $82 million total loss to the segment with the remainder emanating from Bermuda and our London retro book.
Based on our estimate market share as published by the Superintendant of Insurance in Chile and assuming an industry loss of $6 billion to $8 billion, which we believe to be the case, our net loss is well below what peer market share analysis would indicate. This is principally due to fairly aggressive use of what I would describe as spot retrocession purchasing in the region.
The distribution of this loss into the industry with perhaps upwards of 80% to 90% into the ReInsurance market, is reflective of some broader issues in emerging markets we believe need to be addressed by the industry. This would include heavy reliance on proportional Insurance, event or assess the limits on these structures at levels that make them virtually meaningless, inadequate underlying rate levels and commission structures that do not allow sufficient margin to fund events of this magnitude.
While the event will obviously provide the market with an opportunity to address underlying rate adequacy, we will also advocate significant structural change in the market, principally a reliance on nonproportional ReInsurance, our preferred product.
As we’ve mentioned in our last few calls, market conditions remain challenging. We’ve kept our top line flat due principally to recaptured business that was lost at year-end 2008 and selected new opportunities, mostly in Europe.
We are broadly concerned about market conditions however. For example, our Japanese cap portfolio just turned over April 1, with a risk adjusted reduction in pricing of 5.5%. This is in a market that clearly needed more rate as we entered the renewal, and as a result, we reduced our position in this very important market yet again.
On the long tail side as David mentioned, there is broad competition across the market although we do see pockets of positive in some areas of the professional lines and U.K. for example. Overall, we’re very pleased with our underwriting performance against this backdrop and we will continue to be vigilant with our underwriting as this phase of the market plays itself out.
With that, I will turn it back to David for Q&A.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don’t think it would do us any good to comment on any specific will or won’t. I would refer you simply to our general guidance about capital management. We believe the first job is to make sure we have enough capital to weather any storm according t
componenttext:
I don’t think it would do us any good to comment on any specific will or won’t. I would refer you simply to our general guidance about capital management. We believe the first job is to make sure we have enough capital to weather any storm according to our standards, not just the rating agencies and the regulators.
We would second of course, look for where else in our sector we could put it to work for good advantage for our shareholders, and then third, if we had enough by the first test and by the second test, and had nowhere advantageous to put it, then we would look at returning it to our shareholders by whatever we thought was the best method and obviously in doing so, we would always want to do so in a wise way and being opportunistic would be one of the wise ways to do so.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Have you had any discussions with the rating agencies about capital assets monitoring? You monitor your own capital, but the rating agencies do have the badge and the gun to some extent.
componenttext: Have you had any discussions with the rating agencies about capital assets monitoring? You monitor your own capital, but the rating agencies do have the badge and the gun to some extent.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: There’s no doubt about that. It’s a big gun. We are in constant contact with our rating agencies. I always have to let them speak for themselves. It’s inappropriate for me to do so. I can only tell you that from our end, we consider those conversati
componenttext: There’s no doubt about that. It’s a big gun. We are in constant contact with our rating agencies. I always have to let them speak for themselves. It’s inappropriate for me to do so. I can only tell you that from our end, we consider those conversations to be very constructive. Obviously, they can see these results just as you can. We think all the markers of the strengthening and healthy franchise are present.

componenttextpreview: There is noise in the year over year top line numbers and we would suggest that when you normalize for all of those various elements, the noise whether FX or programs that we’re exiting that are running off versus growth in lines that we’re very posit
componenttext:
There is noise in the year over year top line numbers and we would suggest that when you normalize for all of those various elements, the noise whether FX or programs that we’re exiting that are running off versus growth in lines that we’re very positive about, I would put it really in Insurance kind of near the 10% range would be the actual kind of preferred book on preferred book growth.
So we’re very pleased with that number. We examine ourselves very closely given the market conditions and remain pleased. On ReInsurance, it’s flattish over time, maybe even slightly negative.
But in terms of pricing, I’ll let my colleagues who are even closer to the markets talk about that.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, I’m saying that’s the way to normalize for this quarter. I have no reason to change what we told you at the beginning which is we’re looking at low single-digit growth.
componenttext: No, I’m saying that’s the way to normalize for this quarter. I have no reason to change what we told you at the beginning which is we’re looking at low single-digit growth.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me take both questions, both your premium question as well as your loss ratio questions in terms of the stability of the accident result. First, just to amplify what Mike said, from a premium standpoint in the segment, you’ve got to recall, we certa
componenttext:
Let me take both questions, both your premium question as well as your loss ratio questions in terms of the stability of the accident result. First, just to amplify what Mike said, from a premium standpoint in the segment, you’ve got to recall, we certainly do painfully, the first quarter of 2009 was the most challenging time for us and our retentions had actually dropped down to 73%.
This quarter, our retentions are up almost to 86% so keep that in mind as you think about growth quarter to quarter. The other piece is new business. We had planned for a considerable increase over the new business result we achieved last year this quarter. We actually surpassed new business on that basis, but we’re far short of what the planned assumption was primarily because of market conditions.
And I would also say as Mike commented on, that part of our new business success was tied to customers coming home if you will, people that we know very well in terms of profitability. So from a production standpoint, we feel good about the segment results when you flatten out all the one-off anomalies.
Let me quickly also before I turn it over to Jamie, maybe address your observation on the loss ratio, and actually when you do strip out cat activity and prior year development, we saw a slight improvement from first quarter 2010 as compared to first quarter 2009, and actually a fairly stable result quarter to quarter.
And your point was how are we doing that despite rate earn through which would suggest a negative impact. First of all, we actually started to change the pricing trend about a year ago this time, but I would say that earning though now would create a bit of an increase in the loss ratio. But a couple of things to keep in mind, first in the first quarter, we had less noncat property losses, especially in our international book.
That is one positive effect. The other, we have exited less attractive businesses over the past six quarters. Abco, W. Brown, and some parts of our environmental, U.S. Marine and the remaining remnants of our surety business. We are picking up a bit of it in a related shift if you will in related business.
And then the last one I’d say is we’ve continually become better at risk management and underwriting modeling. All those things have added up to stabilize the loss ratio despite pricing pressure.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: As far as ReInsurance is concerned the accident year loss ratio is affected by several facts. One is business mix. In the first quarter of 2009, property cat represented 16% of our net earned premium. It’s now 21%. And we did reduce our position in the
componenttext:
As far as ReInsurance is concerned the accident year loss ratio is affected by several facts. One is business mix. In the first quarter of 2009, property cat represented 16% of our net earned premium. It’s now 21%. And we did reduce our position in the trade credit business quite substantially, so there’s a big business mix change.
In addition, during quarters three and four of 2009, we took 2.7 and 2.5 loss ratio points from impacts from old structured product contracts. And finally, during this quarter, we enjoyed the benefit of $12 million of reinstatement premium on a nonproperty program in Europe, which contributed quite substantially.
In terms of growth, in ReInsurance we try not to predict things too much because it can be lumpy depending on the amount of renewal activity we have in each quarter. As you know, the first quarter is very heavy, the second quarter is reasonably light and then we move into July 1 very heavy and then virtually none the rest of the year. It’s all going to depend on market conditions.

componenttextpreview: We do have the European Investment Bank contacts that are a legacy of the settlement that we had with the SCA back when I first got here. At this point, the notional values on that are about, because of FX principally in terms of reduction are down to abo
componenttext:
We do have the European Investment Bank contacts that are a legacy of the settlement that we had with the SCA back when I first got here. At this point, the notional values on that are about, because of FX principally in terms of reduction are down to about $869 million. This is down about $50 million since the last call, but again, that’s all exchange.
The transactions continue to be rated between Triple B minus to Triple B plus by S&P. Their maturity dates are way out there, 28 to 27 to 2038. You’ll remember that we’re only going to be, first of all these are principal and the interest. We’re only called in if of course, the project fails and FCA fails to respond, and then it could come to us.
In terms of the particular countries, in the two countries you raise, there’s a toll road in Spain and a toll road in Portugal as a part of those - I think it’s actually five bonds covering four projects.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: We do. You’ll recall that when they put us on negative outlook, and I want to pause it. The history gets to be a bit of a blur at this stage. But when they put us on the negative outlook and dropped the rating that would have been in December of ’08.
componenttext:
We do. You’ll recall that when they put us on negative outlook, and I want to pause it. The history gets to be a bit of a blur at this stage. But when they put us on the negative outlook and dropped the rating that would have been in December of ’08.
As you’ll recall, at that time, they put in that they would be open under various conditions to be looking at the rating again, and they gave it kind of a 2-year horizon, and we’ve obviously now I guess five quarters or so into that horizon. So we continue to report what we consider to be our good progress and we continue to hope that this will cause from them a reaction.
By the way, we very quickly looked up the expirations you were looking for, or maturations I should say. The bonds in Spain are actually two separate bonds. One is in 2030 and one is in 28. In Portugal, it’s one bond and it’s 2027.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Is it too early to speculate on what the impact on offshore energy pricing from the oil rig disaster? And then in regards to your success of win backs in the quarter, to what degree do you think clients are still rating agency sensitive or maybe to what d
componenttext: Is it too early to speculate on what the impact on offshore energy pricing from the oil rig disaster? And then in regards to your success of win backs in the quarter, to what degree do you think clients are still rating agency sensitive or maybe to what degree you might see more of those should you see things like that negative removed from S&P?

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: With respect to marine pricing, I’d ask my colleagues to comment again there. They’re spending more time closer to the markets. I would only preface any comment with a simple observation that if logic dictated pricing, we wouldn’t talk about declini
componenttext:
With respect to marine pricing, I’d ask my colleagues to comment again there. They’re spending more time closer to the markets. I would only preface any comment with a simple observation that if logic dictated pricing, we wouldn’t talk about declining pricing in many of our segments at all. So we have to be careful before we predict where the market will do even with what logic would tell us what it should do.
On the win backs and sensitivity to ratings, gosh you know, we noticed throughout the crisis if the market had been overwhelming rating sensitive, we would have lost a lot of business. Instead, a lot of business stayed with us right through the challenges.
We like to think that’s because our front line people are so capable and stayed together. But that caused our clients to want to continue to be backed by XL. So where there are those cases where a long time client took kind of a holiday from us, we work hard to welcome them back and we’re very encouraged by that progress.
I don’t think it’s a change in their view in how rating agencies work. I just think it’s an increased comfort in XL and we think that’s terrific. Rating agencies are important to us and we’ll continue to work to improve our standing with the two, that being S&P and Fitch who still have us on a negative outlook.
But in terms of the marine pricing, David.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: I’m not sure I’d say much more than what Mike said other than if history repeats itself, you’ll probably see some reaction to this loss. We’re in the market for the long haul and we’ll evaluate risks but I would imagine this is probably going to
componenttext:
I’m not sure I’d say much more than what Mike said other than if history repeats itself, you’ll probably see some reaction to this loss. We’re in the market for the long haul and we’ll evaluate risks but I would imagine this is probably going to cause some people to pause.
And I would also just amplify on Mike’s observation around Insurance values and rating agencies, I think it’s still there, but the one thing, and Mike and I just had a change to visit with a lot of clients. I think over the last couple of years, and you have to keep in mind, clients are also very aware and interested in what rating agencies do from their own business perspective. I think they’ve become much more sophisticated relative to understanding the true financial strength and trends of companies and I think there’s a couple of different places clients look for now to give them insight and they don’t rely solely on rating agencies.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from [ Amud Reza, Bauman Capital. ]
componenttext: Your next question comes from [ Amud Reza, Bauman Capital. ]

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: It sounds like this pricing is taking the wrong turn for us right now in the primary markets. What should we be looking to, given that you’ve been in different pricing cycles, what would an outsider have to look towards for potentially seeing pricing in
componenttext: It sounds like this pricing is taking the wrong turn for us right now in the primary markets. What should we be looking to, given that you’ve been in different pricing cycles, what would an outsider have to look towards for potentially seeing pricing increasing.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: That’s a great question. I think around this table we have people who have been through several complete cycles and we all know that there is theoretical tea leaves and we also know that every cycle we either lived through or have examined on a historic
componenttext:
That’s a great question. I think around this table we have people who have been through several complete cycles and we all know that there is theoretical tea leaves and we also know that every cycle we either lived through or have examined on a historical basis, acted in an extremely unpredictable and idiosyncratic way.
The most obvious is when you have some massive change in the capital base of the industry. We saw signs of that happening due to the credit crisis and then as the credit crisis back off, everybody calmed down about capital as a part of the component.
At the same time, you have I think these days, on a relative scale compared to say a decade ago, you have fewer management teams running larger books of business with greater emphasis on bottom line results, and you would think that would start to kick in here as the results run out of the benefit of prior year reserves and run into more difficult conditions.
Those are obviously industry-wide comments. And I just think you could get a turn from any of those things, but the reality is, right now whereas there were some optimistic signs in our pricing as you moved through last year toward the end of the year, it’s kind of reversed itself in a small way at this stage, and we’ll just have to wait and see.
I can’t give you a better answer than that. I think it will be what it will be and we know that our job is to manage through the cycle, and that means we stay disciplined about our underwriting criteria. We don’t let it lag, and we’re very cautious about the other inputs that could affect the book of business that’s in place like inflation and the rest.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Is it fair to say in the framework that you laid out, in other words the first test of capital would be that one that’s rock solid not only with the rating agency standards but your own internal standards, and then secondly go after the organic opportun
componenttext: Is it fair to say in the framework that you laid out, in other words the first test of capital would be that one that’s rock solid not only with the rating agency standards but your own internal standards, and then secondly go after the organic opportunities which it sounds like those aren’t really presenting themselves in a great plethora of opportunities given the pricing environment. Would it be fair to say you might be opportunistic on the capital management or buy back issue but those first two pillars have been fulfilled, i.e., believe you have a rock solid capital base and that organic opportunities may not be abundant.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: No question that XL feels very good about its capital position today and as a result, we are examining the other stages if you will of our examination. We’re just working our way through it. One thing that we have to keep in mind is that you can’t rea
componenttext:
No question that XL feels very good about its capital position today and as a result, we are examining the other stages if you will of our examination. We’re just working our way through it. One thing that we have to keep in mind is that you can’t really overly - well you would know from your own business, market timing is a dangerous way to live.
So what you really have to be thinking about is where is deep value in terms of those either sectors or teams or operations out there that you think could meet the kinds of demands and hurdle rights and philosophy that this firm holds. And if you find an opportunity in any of those dimensions, teams or whatever else, you have to kind of take it when it comes and you can’t just do it according to your view when exactly a particular pricing environment might change.
So it isn’t as definitively colored by current market conditions as I think your question would imply.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010

componenttext: I was hoping you could talk a little bit more about the cat losses, not so much the Chilean and the European storms, but I was surprised at the knock on wood how low the cat losses were excluding those charges, particularly property cat. componenttext: From an Insurance perspective, the other storms that you might be referring to are frankly, events that we wouldn’t expect to have much loss from given where we write business and the type of business that we write. And again, whether you’re talking about Xynthia or maybe some of the Australian floods, those losses came out for us, as we would have expected which were very, very small from an Insurance perspective.

It looks like there’s been disclosure there. Maybe you could just give us a little color as well.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: On Page 7 of the fixed income supplement, we have added some information there on the five countries that are talked about a lot and focused on these days, and you can see in there, it’s $275 million to nonfinancial and $212 to financial. One thing I wo
componenttext: On Page 7 of the fixed income supplement, we have added some information there on the five countries that are talked about a lot and focused on these days, and you can see in there, it’s $275 million to nonfinancial and $212 to financial. One thing I would point out though is that most of our financial exposures to these five countries are to large established global banks that don’t necessarily have a heavy exposure to their local economies.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Doug Mewhirter, RBC.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Doug Mewhirter, RBC.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010

componenttext: There were some movements in the quarter, but we tend to be hedged in terms of our income statement overall in terms of the fact that we have expenses through losses and G&A expenses that roughly match the premium by currency. If we look at it against the prior year, there was about $40 million in gross premium was the impact arising from foreign exchange, but when we take it down to the bottom line in the income statement, we actually think the impact was $2 million or $3 million, almost nothing.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Brian Meredith, UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Brian Meredith, UBS.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: In the Life Insurance area, I noticed that claims and policy benefits was down pretty significantly both year over year and sequentially. Anything unusual happening in that number or is that a good run rate to look at?
componenttext: In the Life Insurance area, I noticed that claims and policy benefits was down pretty significantly both year over year and sequentially. Anything unusual happening in that number or is that a good run rate to look at?

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: There’s 2 things. As Jamie commented on, we did exit three contracts in the Life area. They were recaptured by decedent and we did record a gain of just over $13 million from that. As ever, these things are impacted by foreign exchange movements. It’s
componenttext: There’s 2 things. As Jamie commented on, we did exit three contracts in the Life area. They were recaptured by decedent and we did record a gain of just over $13 million from that. As ever, these things are impacted by foreign exchange movements. It’s mostly a European book in terms of the underlying currency. So those two things will really be the drivers in the quarter. You’ll see relatively equivalent movements in the investment portfolio as well.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: It looking like you exited on of your investment affiliate relationships. Is that true or is there something else going on there?
componenttext: It looking like you exited on of your investment affiliate relationships. Is that true or is there something else going on there?

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: We did. We held back one of our insurers to the principals during the quarter so that was NKP. We wish them luck. They’ve been a great partnership for us, but they reached the point where they felt growing by themselves would be beneficial.
componenttext: We did. We held back one of our insurers to the principals during the quarter so that was NKP. We wish them luck. They’ve been a great partnership for us, but they reached the point where they felt growing by themselves would be beneficial.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: You gave us what your property exposure is to the Horizons rig. I wonder if you could tell us a little bit more about where you think your liability exposure could potentially be here. Is it with your excess liability and what are you net lines in that ar
componenttext: You gave us what your property exposure is to the Horizons rig. I wonder if you could tell us a little bit more about where you think your liability exposure could potentially be here. Is it with your excess liability and what are you net lines in that area?

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think it’s just too early and too murky to tell. As you can tell throughout the day, there’s been all kinds of accelerated speculation in this as to the questions you’ve asked, and I just don’t think we’re going to do any good for anybody incl
componenttext:
I think it’s just too early and too murky to tell. As you can tell throughout the day, there’s been all kinds of accelerated speculation in this as to the questions you’ve asked, and I just don’t think we’re going to do any good for anybody including shareholders by speculating on where it goes.
I think this will become clearer over time, and if there’s anything that reaches the level of exposure, we’ll be right at it.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Ian Gutterman, Adage Capital.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Ian Gutterman, Adage Capital.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: You said there was a positive premium adjustment. I think it was $15 million. What was that from? I’m used to thinking in this point of the economy of negative premium adjustments.
componenttext: You said there was a positive premium adjustment. I think it was $15 million. What was that from? I’m used to thinking in this point of the economy of negative premium adjustments.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: We had a series of reinstatement premiums in the book that did not arise from natural catastrophes and these are lumpy as to when they come through and when we recognize them. It just so happened we had about $15 million more this quarter than we did in t
componenttext: We had a series of reinstatement premiums in the book that did not arise from natural catastrophes and these are lumpy as to when they come through and when we recognize them. It just so happened we had about $15 million more this quarter than we did in the prior year quarter.

componenttext: What types of business would that be from?

componenttext: Mostly casualty.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010

componenttext: Just to clarify on the Chilean reinstatements, do you have the numbers by segment because it looked like on Page 13 of the supplement, I located a little bit of data on it, but it was a little bit confusing because no net earned so I was confused by that.

componenttextpreview: The reinstatement premiums were almost exclusively a ReInsurance segment story. There was nothing really in Insurance, but in ReInsurance the gross written was about $7.5 million, but the net written was a negative a half so we had $7.5 million.
componenttext: The reinstatement premiums were almost exclusively a ReInsurance segment story. There was nothing really in Insurance, but in ReInsurance the gross written was about $7.5 million, but the net written was a negative a half so we had $7.5 million.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: So that’s why I was confused. What caused those to be different from each other?
componenttext: So that’s why I was confused. What caused those to be different from each other?

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Inwards business on the inward and our purchasing on the outwards.
componenttext: Inwards business on the inward and our purchasing on the outwards.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: To follow up on Chile, can you give us a little bit of color on, I guess a fair amount of the ReInsurance loss was local players. Can you give us a sense of across the Insurance and the ReInsurance business how much exposure you would have had to global t
componenttext: To follow up on Chile, can you give us a little bit of color on, I guess a fair amount of the ReInsurance loss was local players. Can you give us a sense of across the Insurance and the ReInsurance business how much exposure you would have had to global treaties or global players and any quota share, any retro? Or are we looking mostly at XL cat?

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think as I mentioned, about $66 million of the $82 million was from our XL Latin American unit where exclusively from proportional ReInsurance. Their cat exposure was practically nil. The rest of it would have been a very small amount in the whole accou
componenttext: I think as I mentioned, about $66 million of the $82 million was from our XL Latin American unit where exclusively from proportional ReInsurance. Their cat exposure was practically nil. The rest of it would have been a very small amount in the whole account portfolio here in Bermuda and the remainder would have been in the retro account in the London operation.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Out of that $66 million are those cat quota shares? What’s the rest of those developing?
componenttext: Out of that $66 million are those cat quota shares? What’s the rest of those developing?

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Virtually all of them have either a session limit or an event limit. As I mentioned, it’s all based on modeling now. We think we’ve done a pretty thorough job that. We’ve been in contact with all of our customers. It is an earthquake loss. It’s sl
componenttext: Virtually all of them have either a session limit or an event limit. As I mentioned, it’s all based on modeling now. We think we’ve done a pretty thorough job that. We’ve been in contact with all of our customers. It is an earthquake loss. It’s slow developing. There’s always that possibility, but we think we’ve got a pretty good handle on it at this point.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can you give us a sense of how far away you are from the caps?
componenttext: Can you give us a sense of how far away you are from the caps?

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: We’re well away from them. As I mentioned, that’s one of the issues down there, is the caps are put in. There are session limits. The limitations we’ve had on our own losses has been with our own purchasing not caps on the underlying structures them
componenttext: We’re well away from them. As I mentioned, that’s one of the issues down there, is the caps are put in. There are session limits. The limitations we’ve had on our own losses has been with our own purchasing not caps on the underlying structures themselves.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: And on the retro side, the risk that your ReInsurance claims just are not getting the accounting information and they’re giving you bad estimates. What’s the risk of development from that side?
componenttext: And on the retro side, the risk that your ReInsurance claims just are not getting the accounting information and they’re giving you bad estimates. What’s the risk of development from that side?

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Very little. Our retro portfolio in London really doesn’t have a tremendous amount of exposure in Latin America. Where we think there’s exposure, we’ve just put the limit up.
componenttext: Very little. Our retro portfolio in London really doesn’t have a tremendous amount of exposure in Latin America. Where we think there’s exposure, we’ve just put the limit up.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: I’m puzzled at the improvement and whether we look year over year or sequential with the trend of ’09, it’s still a big improvement and I’m looking for the supplement at where you’ve been growing and I see more growth in cash and property, so I
componenttext: I’m puzzled at the improvement and whether we look year over year or sequential with the trend of ’09, it’s still a big improvement and I’m looking for the supplement at where you’ve been growing and I see more growth in cash and property, so I’m not quite sure I buy into the mix shift issue. Are there other things going on? You mentioned the light attrition losses. Are you deal picks lower this year versus last year? Are there other lines where it makes sense for the picks to be lower versus what we think as a general trend of prices getting worse?

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me take the casualty growth because a fair amount of that was with us. If you’ll notice we had $42 million of growth in ReInsurance casualty writing. That’s split basically equally between the reinstatement premium item that Simon mentioned before
componenttext: Let me take the casualty growth because a fair amount of that was with us. If you’ll notice we had $42 million of growth in ReInsurance casualty writing. That’s split basically equally between the reinstatement premium item that Simon mentioned before, about $12.5 million of recaptured business that we had lost in that market at the end of 2008. We did see some opportunities to write a couple of new deals. The U.K. motor market is strengthening significantly and we found a few opportunities.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Does casualty have higher picks in the property business so therefore wouldn’t there be an adverse mix shift?
componenttext: Does casualty have higher picks in the property business so therefore wouldn’t there be an adverse mix shift?

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Remember you’re looking at loss ratios on earned premium not written. That business was brand new in the quarter and the earnings would have been fairly diminous.
componenttext: Remember you’re looking at loss ratios on earned premium not written. That business was brand new in the quarter and the earnings would have been fairly diminous.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the Insurance side, is there any going on with DNO or political risk or anything like that where it would make sense that the picks would be much lower this year than last year?
componenttext: On the Insurance side, is there any going on with DNO or political risk or anything like that where it would make sense that the picks would be much lower this year than last year?

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: We don’t do political risk, but from a DNO perspective, no. And really, the key thing for us is the benefit that we’re starting to see earnings through on business that’s been shed, that has been not as attractive, i.e. lower margins. And it doesn
componenttext:
We don’t do political risk, but from a DNO perspective, no. And really, the key thing for us is the benefit that we’re starting to see earnings through on business that’s been shed, that has been not as attractive, i.e. lower margins. And it doesn’t necessarily show up on the one page in the financial supplement.
A good example of that is within our specialty and casualty, there’s some pieces that are actually growing a bit with some of our sub products where the profits are pretty strong still and then there’s other lines that are being to a large degree, eliminated totally.
So underneath those product line groups, you see a lot of action. But for Insurance it is really the benefit of earning through a better loss ratio because we’ve got a higher concentration of more profitable business.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: I wouldn’t want to leave with you with the sense that you framed the question of a combined ratio too, and do remember that we were still in the throes of our expense reductions when you look on a quarter over quarter basis and so 2.7 points of the impr
componenttext: I wouldn’t want to leave with you with the sense that you framed the question of a combined ratio too, and do remember that we were still in the throes of our expense reductions when you look on a quarter over quarter basis and so 2.7 points of the improvement are directly attributable to the charge that we had taken for the expense reduction. So while we’re very pleased with the underwriting performance and what we do see as real improvements, you could over read them if you don’t back that out.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Again, we’re into a speculative area that I’ve chosen not to comment on earlier, so I think I’ll still choose not to comment on it now. The one thing we could have the limitation up on our current authorization, and that’s obviously the first plac
componenttext: Again, we’re into a speculative area that I’ve chosen not to comment on earlier, so I think I’ll still choose not to comment on it now. The one thing we could have the limitation up on our current authorization, and that’s obviously the first place to look, but again, these are matters that we consider on a regular basis as part of our overall capital management and we’ll just have to leave it at that for now. I appreciate the point of curiosity, but it’s just something that we’re going to keep thinking about.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: I’m showing no further questions.
componenttext: I’m showing no further questions.

headline: XL Capital Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just to conclude, on this end we very much appreciate your time. I know David and the team are available for further questions and if there’s anything that we can further clarify around some of these questions, we’re always happy to do so.I will tel
componenttext:
Just to conclude, on this end we very much appreciate your time. I know David and the team are available for further questions and if there’s anything that we can further clarify around some of these questions, we’re always happy to do so.
I will tell you we are very pleased with this quarter. We think it is showing the real signs of what, I guess the real financial evidence of doing what we say we will do and we hope that will be a continuing mark of this management team. Thank you very much for your time.
